I don't subscribe to the idea that a deity influences the micro or macro mechanics of our universe, yet I have never felt comfortable with the delivery method of "New Atheists" like Richard Dawkins. Their facts, mind you, I completely agree with, but their militant "science or you're a fool" dogma leaves me intellectually fulfilled and emotionally empty. I'm a moderate at heart: I don't like labeling myself, backing into a corner and then fighting everyone who isn't in complete alignment with me. Instead, I take joy in unification – bringing ideas, people, philosophies together. Dawkins, Hitchens and the like never gave me tools to unify the mechanics of the natural world with "emergent" concepts like the concept of "self", nor did they help me bridge the gap with others - especially theists. Sean Carol's book tries to.Carroll introduces (or reinforces, if you're already there) some tough-to-swallow naturalist concepts: - humans are a complexity rising from an intermediate state of a low-entropy universe seeking its high-entropy final state, - time is not a fundamental building block of the universe, - a sufficiently powerful computer with enough information can predict everything that will happen in the universe…But while doing so, he compartmentalizes these concepts, and allows for other descriptions of the universe – Newtonian mecanics, causality, memories, morality, free will, the color red – to have importance and value. He gives macroscopic phenomena and vocabularies as much validity as their abilities to be useful in the domains that they operate. For example, when we shoot a rocket into space, we're not using string theory to get it there, we're using Newtonian mechanics, and it is valid and true - even though string theory describes the fundamental building blocks behind it. He calls this "poetic naturalism" – a label I take issue with, but I'm not a fan of labels in general. Once this structured way of thinking is presented, the book dives into the typical heady questions usually encountered in debates about reality. For someone who's steeped in this stuff, much of it is familiar. But the review of the material is fun, and for me – someone who studied computer science and physics at university – it's neat seeing your favorite homework topics (Bayes Nets, genetic algorithms, Schrödinger's equation) glued together into a continuum of philosophical arguments. That said, chapters start reading like a manual of defensive arguments against people with slightly different viewpoints attacking you at a bar. The inspirational feel dies quickly.In fact, about halfway through the book, waves of sadness came over me. Once in a while, Carroll hints at how amazing life is not in spite of, but because of how we've emerged from the process of the universe – but it's nowhere near Sagan's "we are made of star stuff" feel-good messaging that people like Neal deGrasse Tyson attempt to carry the torch on. In the end, Carroll's not here to cheer you up, he's here to wake you up and give you a framework. But he's also not abrasively militant like a Dawkins.In the final section of the book, "Caring", Carroll does attempt to bring purpose and emotion back in - and rightfully kicks the whole thing off with a quote from Carl Sagan's wife. There are nice kernels of life philosophy in this section, and it truly attempts to spline the seemingly harsh edge between naturalism and finding meaning and guidance in your life. "Water doesn’t stop being wet when you learn it's a compound of hydrogen and oxygen," he says. By his own admission, poetic naturalism isn't mean to supply this layer. This section, therefore, is much more about the schools of thought, and the challenges faced in creating these moral, ethical and inspirational layers of life. The true decisions on how to proceed is left as an exercise to the reader. Yet he does provide some guidance in the form of "10 Considerations". In the end, Carroll's framework can be considered somewhat moderate, as he does soften up the harsh edges of pure Naturalism. In doing so, Carroll falls into the state most moderates do – everyone gets mad at him. After reading his book, I sought out critical discussions of it online. I found that non-poetic pure Naturalists are upset that he yields validity to macro (emergent) descriptions on the universe at all. Theists argue that he's ignoring the actual questions theology answers, and his definition of "useful" is arbitrary. But this is exactly what draws me in – he's trying to reconcile the irreconcilable. He doesn't slam the door on theists – he just creates a fair and uncaring framework in which they can play too, and shows them just how much work they have to do to have their ideas rise to the top.Back to the term "poetic". I believe this word should be saved for the layer that helps pick up where naturalism ends. For the masses, it's not enough to provide a framework and enumerate choices. We need to accept, comfort, guide, and inspire people with broader backgrounds, IQs, and needs. Has anyone taken something like the 10 Considerations and weaved them into parables and fanciful tales that help indoctrinate people to the school of thought? Is there a book of The Gospels to be had here? Carroll's drive to understand the universe is compelling for many, but it's not enough for most. Poetic naturalism's view of reality is difficult and stark, and we need a compatibility layer to truly motivate mankind with it.

Finished reading Sean Carroll’s book “The Big Picture: On the Origins of Life, Meaning, and the Universe Itself.” Carroll is a cosmologist and a physicist at Caltech. But this book is not exactly a physics text, rather a philosophical manifesto of what Carroll terms “poetic naturalism.” A physicist putting himself in the shoes of a philosopher? Why not? There was a time when physics was referred to as natural philosophy, and it saddens me that contemporary philosophy and liberal arts in general have parted ways with STEM fields in the past century so much that differences often seem irreconcilable. It has led some scientists to arrogantly declare philosophy redundant, while some hotheads in humanities, including some of my acquaintances, attack scientists and popularizers of science for dehumanizing people and depriving them of meaning. Oh, well...  Sean Carroll, an outspoken atheist, tries to make naturalism (an idea that only natural, as opposed to supernatural or spiritual, laws and forces operate in the world) more palatable for humans who do need meaning in their lives. His version of naturalism encourages a variety of ways to talk about the world, using language dependent upon the aspect of reality being discussed. Carroll’s view vaguely reminds of certain features of the philosophy of pragmatism, which ridiculously claims that an ideology or proposition is true if it works satisfactorily, that the meaning of a proposition is to be found in the practical consequences of accepting it, and that unpractical ideas are to be rejected. Luckily, he doesn’t offer to adapt the notion of “truth” to what is useful, like some philosophers do. In the last part of the book, Carroll enters the realm of ethics. I think this is the weakest part of the book. Carroll comes out swinging against well-motivated, even if unsuccessful, efforts to search for objective morality. He claims that science cannot help us in determining what is moral and what is not. Instead he offers moral constructivism, a poorly described framework that treads dangerously close to moral relativism.He defends compatibilist view of free will along the lines of philosopher Daniel Dennett. He also offers his own version of Ten Commandments, which are, of course, better than those found in the Bible, but, imho, worse than what you could find in Michael Shermer’s “Moral Arc.” Discussion of problems of studying consciousness is interesting, even though you’ll find no new insights but it can be useful to read if you haven’t immersed yourself in literature on the topic. Few people do. But if you are not a nerd like me, you might find a lot of new things here :).  This book shines when Carroll returns to cosmology and physics. I found quite gripping the part on the origins of life. Discussion of the metabolism-first hypothesis was fascinating. An amazing quote “Life is nothing but an electron looking for a place to rest” (Carroll quotes Nobel Prize-winning physiologist Albert Szent-Györgyi here). And, of course, the big hero of the book was entropy. It is discussed in length and helped me, a non-physicist, better understand its immense role in our universe.  I really enjoyed some parts of this incredibly provocative and ambitious volume. In other parts, the book was not quite convincing. But that’s fine. This is still a tremendous work and a really great text. You must have noticed that one of my favorite authors is neuroscientist/philosopher Sam Harris. I like his books and generally agree with him on many an issue. Known to be one of “the four horses of non-apocalypse” and one of the key figures of “new atheism” (whatever that is), Sam has an army of vocal opponents. Some (like Reza Aslan) knowingly twist his words and distort his views, trying to paint him as a right-wing enabler or even a racist. These days this is what you get for simply indicating that some religious beliefs are more dangerous than others. For instance, Jainism doesn’t have the same problematic dogmas as, say, Islam. However, there are well-intentioned and well-argued criticisms of Sam Harris’s views. To name a few, some came from Fareed Zakaria on religion (even though I tend to agree with Sam on this one), Kevin Kelly on AI, Daniel Dennett and Sean Carroll on free will. Quite a lot of worthy criticism came regarding Sam’s book “Moral Landscape: How Science Can Determine Human Values.” Noteworthy criticism came from Thomas Nagel, Yuval Noah Harari and, again, Sean Carroll. Having read books by these authors, I have to say, they are careful thinkers, and they converge in many ways even if it first seems that they bitterly disagree. Some arguments get resolved. For instance, Dennett and Harris seem to have buried the hatchet. I don’t see why a compatibilist and a determinist couldn’t smoke the peace pipe. Harris also corrected himself regarding the role of science. He now says that it can contribute to determining our values. And by science he means not just hard science but also philosophy. So there you go. We need to listen to one another. THEN and only THEN moral progress is possible.

To start, there are many aspects of this book I did find truly interesting and enlightening. Mr. Carroll is a good writer and intelligent theoretical physicist. He attempted a very comprehensive explanation of everything and did a generally okay job of connecting everything back to a natural world. The science is talked down (which is fine with me, because I am new to study Physics), but this turns into a book of philosophy. The discussion about quantum mechanics, core theory and field theory we very educational and gave me a great perspective on how the physical world works. However, as one gets further into the book his ideas begin to sound more arrogant and condescending to other ideas or explanations. He was quick and decisive to cut many other theories and destroy Theism to its very core. He explanations began with how the microscopic world works naturally and with change and become more complex through arrow of time (entropy) and emergent processes. This seemed to work in the beginning but then he began to contradict himself. Naturalism from my understanding only accepts the most fundamental explanations of the physical world. This means that anything above fundamental or 'emergent' is basically an illusion. Carroll takes this idea and adapts it to a "Poetic Naturalism" which is everything that is fundamental and emergent has a certain vocabulary or useful talk in their domain of applicability. In other words, if we can talk about it and it makes sense in the domain we are investigating it is real and okay to talk about. Unfortunately, this is where the book goes truly philosophical. I could go into explaining the Bayesian reasoning and Chinese rooms and transgender being talked about in two different domains, but the kicker is when he discusses consciousness and decisions. Within two chapters, right around part 6, he suggests the natural universe is already set and that we as people have free will to choose. He carefully tries to tread between explaining free will is truly physical and that we should be cautious when talking across multiple vocabularies. This seems rather convenient when trying to promote "Poetic Naturalism" to leave a legacy for himself. He explains that with all knowledge of the natural universe and equations to explain it we could accurately predict the future, however, we are too mentally incapable that we cannot accomplish this. Therefore, the way we talk about free will and choices is real, because though the path of the universe is determined we don't know it, so our decisions feel real. Then, in the very next chapter, he tries to inspire us that we can assign meaning to our lives by making it up ourselves through our decisions! This seems counterintuitive to say the least. If in reality, our universe is already in a way predetermined what's the point of making up meaning when no matter what we do is already going to be in accordance to what physics dictates in the natural universe. This is where the argument against me would be the do not use multiple vocabularies from different domains comes into play. Well, to be honest, this was done by Carroll when writing off free will in the first place. In my opinion, Carroll is a very intelligent and astute individual, though a little arrogant and overconfident in his ideas. However, its hard to for me to accept every aspect of what he said because he admits to not know everything about the natural world, but enough to have very low credences in certain profound beliefs. Which is a nice way of saying your ideas are dumb and nothing happens when you die. Which I may be able to accept and move on with my life. Nevertheless, because we are of the natural world and live within the natural world; I believe we will never fully understand the full workings of the universe, multiverse or existence. We cannot get out of the universe we are in and therefore are bound by its physics. This does not mean there is nothing else or that universe will just end in a cold abyss of existence and nothing will ever happen again for eternity. That seems to me to be a waste of existence, though Carroll would be quick to say, "The universe doesn't care; it will just follow the law of physics." Lastly, I will not dismiss the knowledge of physics or the natural world that I learned from the book and will continue to contemplate just how everything works. However, this book seems to be missing something. After, reading it I feel empty, meaningless and downright insignificant. Quite frankly, if Carroll believes every word of this I do not know how he gets out of bed in the morning. The lack of meaning or free will is disheartening, not inspiring. Do I keep asking myself why be me?

I've seen Caroll's name pop up here and there, but never read or heard anything until I stumbled upon a clip of his in Joe Rogan explaining Laplacian Determinism, and I really enjoyed it. I liked his personality and I found his way of explaining engaging. I listened to the whole episode afterward, and at some point, he mentioned he had a book on the meaning of life, where he tried to bridge many disciplines together. That was music to my ears given I find that's always where the most value comes from if you do it properly. He also seemed to take philosophy seriously, which gave me some confidence that he might have something worth saying. The whole book is based on what he calls poetic naturalism. Which tries to be the bridge between a sort of reductivist nihilistic materialism and everyday life. What is ultimately real is the quantum world. Our everyday world is purely a human construct (chairs, love, nations), but a useful construct that we are right in regarding as real. A decent portion of the book is sort of a pop-science and pop-philosophy introduction. Although I don't mean that necessarily in a wrong way. It makes it pretty accessible and tries to provide a foundation of what he tries to argue later. A lot of it is to justify a naturalistic worldview, with a supernatural or religious worldview as the antagonist. I find this usually done very poorly. However, I found his approach a lot more humble and grounded than many famous new atheists like Dawkins or Sam Harris. Which I attribute to his above-average philosophical literacy compared to most in that community. Although Dennet is quite an accomplished philosopher, so maybe a good dosing of humility is also required. His Bayesian approach was particularly well-argued. Although not in such technical terms, that was always what drew me towards a naturalistic worldview when I was younger. It shows, to the extent possible, why that worldview is "rational" (or at least why it has some reasoning). I think it provided the best foundation for it out of anything that I have seen. It is mostly based on Hume and with a fancier repackaging and aided by modern statistics and scientific advancements, but he does credit Hume and his presentation of it was well done. The chapter on biology and the emergence of life was also incredibly fascinating and I learned a lot of new things.Nevertheless, despite many positives, I disliked certain things. For one, while I understand and value his approach to naturalism, I do think it ends up being a bit reductionist at times. And while I found him much humbler than most in his position, nevertheless there was a few cases where I thought he overstepped and could have handled the topic better. His understanding of religion is also not the greatest and often misinterprets what its trying to achieve and its role in understanding the role. Often trying to impose a materialistic worldview into a religious one, much like many on the opposite side trying to impose a religious worldview into a materialistic one. Neither works. This was particularly odd to me because he constantly emphasizes the point of that any model is useful for any given context. From Newtonian mechanics to Einstein's relativity, quantum fields, and even our everyday life, with things like relationships. Everything works in its own domain, but if you try to bring one language into another field, it breaks down. Yet he repeatedly mixed a religious and materialistic worldview.In addition, I disliked almost everything he wrote on consciousness. I understand where he comes from, and I think he argues his side well enough, but to be brutally honest I just think he is wrong. He tries to make as if the problems that we have in consciousness aren't problems at all and that's why they have been unsolvable. I didn't quite buy it. And unfortunately, consciousness permeates a fair bit of the book, since it's rather important to retain a coherent naturalistic philosophy. Overall, I quite enjoyed it. I think he did a brilliant job of combining several fields together, exactly what I hoped for. His writing is very good, and I found the structure of the book well organized. Presents science at its best and the appeal and reasoning of a naturalistic worldview against a supernatural one. I disagreed with some topics, but that's mostly disagreeing with his position than anything else. But I think he argued well for his side. Especially for those new to these types of topics like philosophy and religion and want to dip their toes, I think this is a brilliant book.

Sean Carroll, a theoretical physicist from Caltech, masterfully merges science, religion, and philosophy in this fantastic tour de force, investigating the origins of life, consciousness, and the universe itself.Carroll begins his work with a section titled "Cosmos", wherein he gives a very brief overview of the foundation of modern physics: quantum field theory. As best as we can tell, all of reality can be described by fluctuations in fields which permeate the whole of the universe. Carroll even dissects an equation in an Appendix which describes the interactions between our mathematical representations of quantum mechanics, spacetime, gravity, the electroweak force, mass, and more. (An equation which will be familiar to any physics graduate students.)Carroll espouses naturalism, the belief that all the laws and forces that explain the world ultimately have natural (as opposed to supernatural) causes. But he also notes that quantum field theory is just one way of talking about the universe. Different descriptions of nature are useful in different contexts; for instance, Newtonian gravity is extremely useful for describing books falling off of shelves, planets orbiting stars, and even for landing people on the Moon. But it fails to accurately describe the motions of objects moving close to the speed of light or near extremely massive objects (where relativity is required) and in the quantum regime (where no compelling theory has yet been discovered).This doesn't mean that Newton's theory is wrong, just that it's only applicable (and useful) in a particular domain. Carroll believes that useful theories are those that do a good job describing and predicting behavior of the physical world in a particular regime. Different theories can have overlapping regimes, but it can be dangerous to use the terminology of one regime to describe another. Carroll calls this philosophy poetic naturalism, introducing it early in this work and using it as a framework to tie together the rest of the book.Carroll touches on emergence, the idea that complex -- even unpredictable -- behavior can arise from a large system of simple components interacting via simple rules, and gives statistical mechanics / thermodynamics as an example. An individual molecule, for example, has certain motional degrees of freedom when it has a certain amount of kinetic energy available. A gas of a large number of these molecules has "a temperature", which is an emergent property of the underlying molecules' kinetic energies. It's difficult (even counterproductive) to use the vocabulary of individual molecules when trying to deduce a theory of fluid dynamics, but it's nonsensical to try to determine the "temperature" of an individual molecule. These theories describe the same system, but over different domains of applicability.Carroll discusses how emergence, combined with the boundary conditions of the universe (namely, extremely low entropy in the very early universe) allow complex systems to evolve over time without violating any known physical laws. The arrow of time and the phenomenon of emergence allow for the evolution of life, the complexity of the human brain, and even consciousness."So what's the point?" In his conclusion, Carroll tackles the question that many atheists face when asked to confront the apparent absurdity of a life without God. Carroll's answer is that there is no meaning to life save for the meaning individual humans ascribe to it. But the fact that human beings have evolved from these simple physical principles and exist to ascribe any meaning to the universe is an honest-to-goodness miracle in and of itself, no God required: "our emergence has brought meaning and mattering into the world."In the words of the inimitable Carl Sagan, "these are some of the things that hydrogen atoms do, given fifteen billion years of cosmic evolution."

1-10 Takeaways:1) The scientific community has done away with the idea of cause and effect. Not to say that there is no cause and effect but that cause and effect is not a fundamental principle of how the universe works. Cause and effect (unless in an emergent context) is a left over Aristotelian belief; but, we haven't updated our way of looking at the world (proud of myself for using the word "Aristotelian"). Motion, for example, is better understood as forces "doing their thing" rather than effects having causes. 2) Holding onto the belief of cause and effect would regularly result in tracking causes all the way back to the erroneous "unmoved mover" (gap based religion/faith). 3) Laplace posited that the universe is not cause and effect but patterns. Laplace was the first to point out that you can predict what is happening to an object at *any* point of motion. The future and the past of an object are equally known because they are determined by the laws of nature (core theory equation). 3 is not the cause of 4; the pattern is just 3 and then 4 (the universe should be seen like this). There is not an impulse, enchantment or guiding force; instead, the universe is a series of patterns. 4) Particles Field Theory shows that all particles and forces relevant to everyday life are known. We can imagine other particles or forces but they do not exist/impact our everyday lives. 5) Emergence Theory says that an entity can have traits that its parts do not. For example understanding the world on a macro level through cause and effect, arrow of time, etc. is fine.6) Entropy always increases but complexity comes and goes. The complexity of humans at a point later in the timeline of the universe is compatible with the overall increase of entropy overtime. 7) Life is a feature, not a substance. Heat, for example, is a way to talk about molecules. Life, is a way to talk about molecules. Life is not a substance. 8) All questions in life could be answered by, "because of the law of physics and the initial conditions of the universe"; but, on a macro/emergent level it is perfectly fine explaining cause and effect (for example, why is a giraffe's neck long?). 9) In the C. Elegan's flatworm, its neurons were mapped and one neuron was found to tell the flatworm if it was looking at itself or something else. This could be a good demonstration of what is consciousness/what is the origin of consciousness. 10) Mind Body Problem through the lens of Descartes is that there is a material body but an immaterial mind. Princess Elisabeth challenged Descartes, asking him to explain how the immaterial mind would influence a material body. Descartes could not (along with everyone else, for that matter) supply a satisfactory answer. We know all the particles and forces in play on the human body. 11) (Whoops, technically supposed to stop at 10) Carroll introduces what he calls "Poetic Naturalism." Poetic Naturalism is the idea that the only forces are the natural forces but that it is okay to see/understand yourself beyond particles and forces on an emergent level. If you were to see yourself as simply particles and forces then there is no room for freewill, right and wrong, etc.; but, on an emergent level, you can attribute to yourself freewill, right and wrong, etc. This is problematic for people who want objective answers about meaning, right and wrong, etc. because these things cannot be observed on a micro level. There will never be enough science to definitively prove meaning; but, you get to assign your own meaning to your life. 1-10 Questions:1) If you hold a certain faith, do you see your faith (deity, deity powers, etc.) as immaterial? If so, how do you explain your immaterial faith influencing you materially? 2) If you hold a certain faith, why do you choose it? Do you choose your faith as an explanation of the origin of life, a proper code of ethics for your life, because of community, because of personal experience, etc.?

Theoretical physicist, Sean Carroll, offers an amazingly detailed, coherent, and comprehensive survey of what physics has to tell us about "the origins of life, meaning, and the universe itself." Carroll is one of the most elegant, lucid and accessible of the current crop of science writers, perhaps the best since Carl Sagan, and like Sagan, he offers a humanistic, naturalistic view chock full of insights while connecting the dots from varied fields like history, philosophy, art, and science. He begins with a definition and description of the "Cosmos" as he details the fundamental nature of reality and the core particle theory, time's arrow and his particular worldview he calls "Poetic Naturalism."Quoting the poet Muriel Rukeyser, Carroll writes: "The universe is made of stories, not of atoms" and then goes on to say, "The world is what exists and what happens, but we gain enormous insight by talking about it -- telling its story -- in different ways." So what does he mean by "Poetic Naturalism?"Naturalism comes down to three things, he says:1. There is only one world, the natural world.2. The world evolves according to unbroken patterns, the laws of nature.3. The only reliable way of learning about the world is by observing it.Basically, "naturalism" rejects anything supernatural, and says that the world is revealed to us by scientific investigation. The "poetic" aspect comes into play when we begin to speak about that world. It's three points are:1. There are many ways of talking about the world.2. All good ways of talking must be consistent with one another.3. Our purposes in the moment determine the best way of talking.The stories we tell about that world are of three kinds:1. The deepest, most fundamental level: you and I are a collection of sub-atomic particles.2. The emergent, effective level: I am a man named Frank Jude and you are the reader of this review, each of us with our own histories of experience. An eliminativist would say that this level is just an illusion because what we are is simply a collection of sub-atomic parts. A poetic naturalist would say we are no less real for that fundamental level being true. We could speak about us getting up in the morning and making our coffee at that sub-atomic level, but it is more descriptive and helpful to speak about "us" waking up and making that coffee.3. The level of "values" where concepts of right and wrong, purpose, and aesthetics comes in to play. This coffee is better than the coffee made by Starbucks, and the music I am listening while drinking it has more depth and beauty than the shit played on AM radio.He follows this part with "Understanding" where he writes about how we learn about the world, critical thinking, belief, and what we can know about the world based upon the core theory. "Essence" covers quantum mechanics and does a good job of explaining why those woo-meisters (who shall remain nameless here) are either intellectually dishonest or simply do not understand what they are talking about. "Complexity" introduces emergence and as a poetic naturalist, Carroll doesn't minimize or discount the "reality" of emergent properties. With Part Five, he turns his attention to "Thinking" and discussing the emergence of consciousness, with a whole section looking at the so-called "hard problem" and philosophical zombies and other exercises that he shows ultimately fail to do what they are meant to do. He ends his tome with "Caring" where, as a naturalist, he refuses to pull any punches in his discussion of values and ethics.A brilliant tour de force, I recommend this to anyone interested in thinking about "life, meaning and the universe itself!"

In the end this book was great. For the fact that I have never come across such a comprehensive exploration of metaphysical existence, this book alone is a winner. For the fact that this book is so well researched, supported, written, and fair/balanced make it an all time great. Well maybe not a classic, but still a great read. that’s not to say there weren’t flaws. Despite the extremely impressive diversity of opinion and supporting materials used here (from Einstein to Hume to Aristotle to Darwin and everyone in between), the self-proclaimed atheistic poetic naturalist of an author really evangelized his personal conclusions about existence a bit too much. In particular, there were a number of occasions (particularly as it related to God/theism and consciousness) where the author glossed over basic arguments and simply asserted his truth without context in favor of fallacy. Now I can’t expect an atheist to understand theism (and it’s VAST depth and breadth of philosophical schools) well enough to properly and fairly portray its defense here, but there were just enough glaring “really?” moments in some of the assertions about theism and consciousness to irk me. Especially juxtaposed to very intelligent fallacy-free discussion of other topics. It’s as though this clearly thoughtful, intelligent interlocuteur decided to turn on the middle school debate class switch in his brain only to turn it back off on the next page. With that said, overall, I was rather impressed at how fair and articulate this scientist was at being analytical and detailed about physics and scientific details while being equally adept at exploring and arguing philosophically. Even to his ultimate conclusion, he was able to reject theism and existential purpose without projecting nihilism in favor of “poetry”. He was able to convincingly air opinions of meaning, purpose, and value about existence while appealing to nothing but his own commitment to Bayesian existentialism. It was fair and honest about its subjective conclusions while still being willing to admit its potential faults. In the end there are always more questions to answer and plenty of looming discrepancies and inadequacies and unknowns in our universe despite the author’s sometimes absolutist assertions, but many questions herein are answered skillfully and satisfactorily.For that, and that alone I can’t hold this books flaws against it. But there’s so much more value here than just that: from being a well-written and engaging book to being an essential and exceptional volume of current metaphysical thought to having just enough detail to project expertise but not enough to bore to being surprisingly fair and balanced in (mostly) allowing the reader to understand both sides of an argument. I also really enjoyed the author’s commitment to staying founded in physical sciences while trying to tackle huge seemingly non-physical ideas. He did a great job at weaving philosophy and physics together in a rather convincing and enlightening way. This book was a fantastic mental exercise in all the right ways, and it’s a great one for both beginners and more experienced students of existential thought. It’s hard to not come away with some new ideas from this book regardless of your biases. Though, it should be clear to readers to not take these ideas as doctrine or without grains of salt. There’s a lot of good here, but a lot is ignorant of large are more nuanced arguments in favor or the simplified and conclusive picture the author is trying to paint. It’s still a pretty picture in the end, but one that admittedly isn’t absolute or complete I n its beauty.

The Big Picture is a highly ambitious project and whether you agree with all the conclusions or not, you will walk away with many new understandings and marvel at its own internal consistency. In this book finally, we have a natural science professor trying to give his unapologetic, no holds barred, rationalists' view on the nature or purpose of existence. Unlike many other scientists (at least in public domain), he does not shrug off what is unexplained by sciences to the realm of supernatural. And unlike many other rationalist philosophers, the author can and does use exhaustive his scientific knowledge well to make genuinely interesting points. The author's overall construct is novel and impressive although it might be incomplete for an academic philosopher and good enough only for a popular science book. May be, it is not original either but it is for a book of this genre in the readings of this reviewer.The main conclusion, in my words, is that any consistent and falsifiable theory that tries to explain what is going on around in our world is a part of a naturalist's bag of things to understand the world. The following are the main provisos: - Such a theory should be valid in some ways to explain (past or present or future) a part of the world around us - It should be falsifiable with more evidences (explained through Bayesian priors)- It will only be valid in its domain of applicability. Bosons and fermions cannot explain how a cell functions or a theory of cells cannot explain how Facebook evolves - for instance Try explaining water pressure or properties through Hydrogen and Oxygen! - No model can explain all the emergent or manifested facets of reality. New characteristics emerge when one changes the scale (or context of things). This is clearly true when one is dealing with chemicals where compound products have wholly different properties compared to the underlying.The author talks about this being true across realms (from quarks to protons to elements etc all the way to galaxies or from atoms to cells all the way to life, consciousness and history).- And all such theories should be internally consistent.The book goes on to explain some of these island theories that explain existence. Through the usual bag of theories, including relativity, quantum mechanics, biochemistry and evolution, the author describes emergence of ever rising complexity amid perpetually increasing overall chaos (entropy). The author loses his way somewhat when he tries to apply systematic knowledge to human subjects like consciousness, morality, politics and other social/personal issues that have dogged philosophers from time immemorial. If consciousness, for instance, is an emerging phenomenon from physical brain states (like society from a group of individuals), is it totally wrong to talk about it in Cartesian dualistic way (for example once again, is water more than hydrogen and oxygen)? This is where many of the conclusions smack of dogma borne out of pre-conceived biases rather than a result of scientific inquiry. Many overall conclusions on the meaning and the purpose or the way to behave etc will likely warm all rationalist readers but for some conclusions at least, their foundations are as far away from a rational inquiry as in many other fields.

Carroll is a great writer: informational but not didactic, self-assured but not smug. I loved his point of view and would highly recommend this book to anyone, but I'm going to use this space to talk about my problems with the book rather than lavish praise upon it.Carroll argues for a worldview called "poetic naturalism," essentially making a three-part case: (1) the human mind organizes and comprehends existence using stories; (2) science is our best way of telling those stories; and (3) the more our stories accurately reflect reality, the better job we can do of figuring out how to live our lives. The third part of this argument comes in sections 5 and 6 of the book, which focus on consciousness and ethics, respectively. Carroll doesn’t have a very good scientific theory of either consciousness or ethics (which is okay, because neither does anyone else), so he spends a lot of time caught up in overwrought arguments against fanciful thought experiments like "the Chinese room" and "Mary's room," and a truly baffling chapter debating whether or not zombies are plausible (spoiler: they aren't).The point Carroll is trying to get across in the book (usually very successfully) is that the universe can both be one big monistic thing (i.e. a quantum wave function) and an experiential reality which we describe in narrative terms. Thus from a human perspective we should retain any stories or models which we find “useful,” even if we know they're not strictly "true." But of course usefulness is necessarily a subjective trait. For example, when discussing the existential crisis that has bubbled up in millions of minds upon realizing that humans are collections of atoms performing largely without conscious thought, Carroll dismisses it as mere “grumpiness.” His counter-example is that a theist who later becomes an atheist doesn’t find their experience of life diminished just because they’ve stopped believing in God. The problem with this example is that it's plain wrong; a lot of people do find it hard to hold onto love or joy when their ontology shifts. There are many examples like this in the book, in which Carroll tries to empathize with other points of view but ultimately betrays his biases.Similarly, when Carroll grapples with questions of spirituality or the supernatural, his arguments are entirely too Western. The argument that the universe is one big uncontrived monistic thing overlaid with a bunch of contrived human stories is a foundational idea in many Buddhist schools of thought. I'm not trying to say that Buddhism is just a primitive form of quantum physics, but that it represents an ancient and popular mode of thought that Carroll entirely fails to engage with. At one point, he refers to Plato’s model of the mind as a rider steering two horses, and echoes Jonathan Haight's counter-argument that it is actually more like a person riding on an elephant; again, this is almost precisely how most schools of Buddhism depict the mind, and it would have given extra dimension to poetic naturalism as a philosophy to see it engage with something other than Western Christianity. These are just two examples I can easily access because I’m a student of Buddhism, but I’m sure there are many other examples that students of other spiritual or philosophical traditions might find.

"Poetic naturalism is a philosophy of freedom and responsibility. The raw materials of life are given to us by the natural world, and we must work to understand them and accept the consequences. The move from description to prescription, from saying what happens to passing judgment on what should happen, is a creative one, a fundamentally human act. The world is just the world, unfolding according to the patterns of nature, free of any judgmental attributes. The world exists; beauty and goodness are things that we bring to it.""Those swirls in the cream mixing into the coffee? That’s us. Ephemeral patterns of complexity, riding a wave of increasing entropy from simple beginnings to a simple end. We should enjoy the ride.""Life is not a substance, like water or rock; it’s a process, like fire or a wave crashing on the shore. It’s a process that begins, lasts for a while, and ultimately ends. Long or short, our moments are brief against the expanse of eternity.""Meaning in life can’t be reduced to simplistic mottos. In some number of years I will be dead; some memory of my time here on Earth may linger, but I won’t be around to savor it. With that in mind, what kind of life is worth living? How should we balance family and career, fortune and pleasure, action and contemplation? The universe is large, and I am a tiny part of it, constructed of the same particles and forces as everything else: by itself, that tells us precisely nothing about how to answer such questions. We’re going to have to be both smart and courageous as we work to get this right.""The universe is not a miracle. It simply is, unguided and unsustained, manifesting the patterns of nature with scrupulous regularity. Over billions of years it has evolved naturally, from a state of low entropy toward increasing complexity, and it will eventually wind down to a featureless equilibrium. We are the miracle, we human beings. Not a break-the-laws-of-physics kind of miracle; a miracle in that it is wondrous and amazing how such complex, aware, creative, caring creatures could have arisen in perfect accordance with those laws. Our lives are finite, unpredictable, and immeasurably precious. Our emergence has brought meaning and mattering into the world.""The mistake we make in putting emphasis on happiness is to forget that life is a process, defined by activity and motion, and to search instead for the one perfect state of being. There can be no such state, since change is the essence of life. Scholars who study meaning in life distinguish between synchronic meaning and diachronic meaning. Synchronic meaning depends on your state of being at any one moment in time: you are happy because you are out in the sunshine. Diachronic meaning depends on the journey you are on: you are happy because you are making progress toward a college degree. If we permit ourselves to take inspiration from what we have learned about ontology, it might suggest that we focus more on diachronic meaning at the expense of synchronic. The essence of life is change, and we can aim to make change part of how we find meaning in it.""When we want something to be true, when a belief makes us happy—that’s precisely when we should be questioning. Illusions can be pleasant, but the rewards of truth are enormously greater."

“The Big Picture” is a towering exposition on naturalism - more specifically poetic naturalism. The idea of naturalism itself isn’t new. In fact it’s markedly ancient. However, Carroll brings his expertise of Physics to paint a very convincing treatise on naturalism (not the this naturalist reader needed much convincing), and makes a strong case for the “poetic” part of the philosophy.Carroll begins with how it’s useful to use different vocabularies to talk about different aspects of the world at different levels, although the vocabulary might not reflect the fundamental ontology. In particular, we see discussions about how “causes” and “reasons” are very useful ways of talking about humans and the world as we know it, but they don’t reflect the fundamental nature of the world. The impersonal laws of physics do not allude or recognize causes/reasons. A lot of our notion of order/sequence of events, which in turn makes the vocabulary of “causes” and “reasons” useful, can be traced back to the arrow of time - the fact that the universe is continually moving from a state of low entropy to a state of high entropy.We then spend time talking about how to understand this universe. What does it mean to truly know? Is it right to say that we “know” gravity just as well as we know the Pythagoras theorem? Since science is a based on observations through instruments/senses, how do we deal with the fundamental incompleteness in the knowledge? Enter Bayesian reasoning. There is no single, complete way of describing the universe. Different models are useful at different levels, and are helpful in their domain of applicability. The ideas of “emergence” and “strong emergence” are talked about in detail, which I found thoroughly interesting.The book then moves on to describe the current best ideas of physics that describe the fundamental nature of our world - quantum physics and core theory - and how these ideas together can completely describe everything about the world in its domain of applicability.The next section goes on to talk about the “mysterious” phenomenon of complex life. This, to me, was one of the most fascinating sections of the book. Drawing a parallel between the emergence of apparent complexity during the process of coffee and cream mixing together in a cup, and the apparent complexity of the entire universe during the process of moving from the Big Bang to the final heat death of the universe was one of the big takeaways from the book for me.We then discuss one of the great all-time mysteries - consciousness - and how it can be explained by the framework of poetic naturalism which is a fundamentally physical philosophy affording no room for the non-physical. Since much of the science of consciousness is unknown, the arguments presented for naturalism have counter-arguments. Carroll does a fair job of describing differing viewpoints and refrains from definitive statements. We also encounter the great problem of free-will, its implications on actions and consequences, and how poetic naturalism advocates a compatibilistic view of the problem.Finally the book talks about how we can define meaning and purpose in this uncaring, impersonal universe as uncovered by naturalism. We talk about how there no objective morals and no inherent purpose to the entire universe, let alone our existence and our place in it (an unnerving prospect indeed!). But this isn’t necessarily a bad thing. In fact, it is liberating since it provides us with a blank slate to define our own morals and discover a purpose for our existence. A weighty responsibility but not one that is beyond us. This is Carroll is at his poetic best.This is a dense book which is chock full of ideas and concepts (most of which are well known). But the real value for me was that it helped answer, or at any rate clarify, a bunch of questions that I’ve spent time thinking about. It is possible that I especially liked this book since it helped cement many notions that I already held but could not formulate with clarity, however, I believe this book can enjoyed by people from other philosophical backgrounds as well.

There is a meme I like; it's in the form of a Gif animation: first it shows the earth, then the solar system, then our corner of the Milky Way, followed by the entire Milky Way, followed by our cluster of galaxies, followed by super clusters of galaxies, followed by the entirety of observable space...with Jesus standing over it all saying, "Don't masturbate." It makes me laugh every single time.Much like Sapiens: A Brief History of Humankind (one of the best books I've ever read), The Big Picture is a splash of very cold water on the face of anyone who thinks there is anything supernatural in the universe. I don't love reading about physics, but I accept the conclusions of physicists: the universe--everything in it, including me and you--is made up of particles. Particles interact in logical ways. Wave functions, strings, fields, whatever the quantum physicists want to call it all, everything is made of stuff. Beyond the stuff? Nothing. Entropy is real. Time--is it emergent, or fundamental?--passes. Goodness and meaning are ideas that we bring to our existence (again, shades of Yuval Noah Harari). Many of our ideas, like the Bible telling people not to wack off-- are not terribly useful. Other ideas are positive illusions: things people believe in to make themselves feel better, or to create meaning in their lives. And so on. Marcus Aurelius wrote that "all that exists is, in a manner, the seed of what which will be," and he was more right than he knew. Everything that happens next in our universal reality depends entirely on what's happening right now. The miracle isn't that a god created us with souls that can win or lose eternal bliss by our adherence to rules laid out in old books, but that we are, as Carl Sagan said, a way that the cosmos knows itself. From the leptons and quarks and fields of our quantum stuff, our consciousness has arisen, and it is that consciousness that creates so many wonderful things: science. The Avengers. Cheeseburgers. Poetry. Bikinis. Monster movies. Philosophy. Coffee. Love.That's pretty amazing. The author calls all of this 'poetic naturalism,' and I think that's as good a term as I have ever heard. A hard book, but well written and interesting. Complex but not unbearable to read.

I was first introduced to theoretical physicist Sean Carroll via his podcast. For his 100th episode he gave a brief summary of some of the ideas in this book. There are two main questions this book attempts to answer: 1) is naturalism the best explanation for the world around us, including the biggest one, our brains and consciousness itself? (Spoiler alert: he says yes). The second question is, given the naturalist worldview, is there any room for things like "purpose" or "meaning"?Probably over three fourths of the book is devoted to trying to answer the first question, and he does a pretty convincing job. If you are coming in to this book with an already naturalist viewpoint on our universe, then you will still be pleased to find some unique concepts and explanations. For example, the idea of "emergence" and what he calls "poetic naturalism" are big themes throughout the book. An emergent phenomenon is one that uses a certain useful internally consistent description of the world, while not being the most absolute fundamental level at which these things can be understood. A really basic example is using fluid mechanics to describe the air in the room. Just because we know that the air is really made up of gluons and quarks and stuff, does this mean that "fluids" don't really exist or we shouldn't use them to describe the world? The same applies to cells, living organisms, and even human behavior, brains, and consciousness. All of this makes for some not so subtle pushback against the trendy idea in some circles that "consciousness" or "choice" doesn't exist in any meaningful sense. It's possible to understand that the world is made up of particles and fields on a fundamental level, and still accept that emergent descriptions about human behavior and life are useful and even essential ways of understanding it.Only the last few chapters are exclusively dedicated to discussing the ideas of purpose and meaning, and whether or not they exist. I really liked these chapters, and wish these ideas had been expanded a bit more. The bottom line is that even if ethics and morality are not built into the universe at an intrinsic level, they are certainly worthwhile endeavors. In fact, we need to do much more work than we are currently in making sure our ethical system catches up with the rapid technological and scientific changes occurring around us. My favorite answer to the question, does anything in life matter? "The universe doesn't care about us, but we care about the universe. That's what makes us special." "Whenever we ask ourselves whether something matters, the answer has to be found in whether it matters to some person or persons."

I picked this book up partly out of my enthusiasm for science and partly out of the name recognition for Sean Carroll. Like many books I’ve been reading lately, there was much to love about this book and a few things that left me a little disappointed. First off, I loved the amount of information in this book. Carroll doesn’t talk over your head, but he doesn’t really dumb it down too much either. He gives a fairly good explanation of science’s current understanding of the origins of the universe and the origins of life. And I really like how Carroll has a easy-to-understand way to talk about entropy and it’s effect on complexity. I felt like the way that he addressed the various philosophical issues that have commonly arisen alongside these ideas were handled well, and were well balanced. That’s not something that you typically see in books of this nature. By coincidence, I had happened to be reading a Christian apologetic book at the same time as I was reading this. It made for an an interesting dichotomy. Unlike the apologetics book, Carroll isn’t shy about honestly addressing other points of view, and seeing how and why we might, or might not, have credence in certain ideas. He sets forth what we think is likely true, and isn’t ashamed to state what we have no clue about. There’s a real honesty about his writing, and at least a sense of the breadth of human knowledge on these subjects. One of my main complaints about this book, was also ironically something I kind of liked about it: I feel like it was too broad in its scope. On the one hand, it was kind of interesting to see how all of these ideas could flow together with Carroll’s idea of Poetic Naturalism. But on the other, I also found myself wishing I had just a little more information about the subject I was reading about, before I was jerked along to the next one. The chapters where this seemed to be the starkest where those dealing with consciousness. I’ve become interested in this idea of how consciousness might be just an emergent property of a complex enough of a brain. I was kind of hoping I’d get a better sense of what that means, or how it would work. But Carroll didn’t provide much more information about it, beyond the basic idea of complexity and emergence. I guess that might really be the current state of the science around it. There’s still so much that’s unknown. But the fact that he was addressing something that’s so much less understood than all of the other topics of the book, made the last section feel disjointed and, at times, unnecessary.

Lucid exposition of an entire belief system/world view Carroll calls poetic naturalism. Naturalism is the view there is a nature and it follows discoverable laws. Poetic refers to the fact you can have multiple compatible laws describing the same thing at different levels of detail. Which one is most useful is up to you. You have the poetic license to make such a choice.I remember Karl Popper was said to be the favorite philosopher of scientists and engineers. Carroll offers himself up as a serious contender for that title. Of course, a lot of the basic tenets are not necessarily new, but Carroll offers a latest iteration of update and interpretation. His analysis is sharp and to the point. Case in point, a lot of people jumped on the notion of fine-tuning to immediately re-embrace theism. Carroll will show you that the theism explains precisely nothing about the fine-tuning. In fact, you are just suffering from confirmation bias. When you read a typical philosophical work, there are almost always passages that get you more and more confused, even though ever so subtly. One concept/argument not yet well defined is expended to more and more sentences, each subject to some additional degree of uncertainty in interpretation. But voila, at the end of long passage, the conclusion is extraordinarily proved beyond reasonable doubt. And you are left none the wiser. It is when the philosophers use concrete examples when the ambiguity is minimized. This is the time when their non-clear thinking is exposed and can thus be debunked. John Searle produced the Chinese room analogy. Now we understand that he doesn’t comprehend the property of emergence. This is an unmitigated good thing for all involved. The readers need not worry there is some deep meaning the writing is conveying that we just didn’t get. The author can now update his/her knowledge to be more complete. The meaning of life or how to live your life are issues that come up a lot in philosophical writing. Carroll will calmly admit the knowledge of the nature doesn’t give you any conclusion. Here again Searle begged to differ and tried to use many sentences to prove one can derive ethics (”ought to”) from what is. Carroll shows that Searle snuck in an assumption in one step of his “derivation”. Even though poetic naturalism doesn’t give you a prescription on ethics, it does warn you away from the false complacency associated with the conviction that some morals are objectively the best. Overall, this is what you expect from a true scientist: you’ll be told what we do and do not know.

3.5This is a very disorderly book, jumping around a lot more than I would have liked. He is at his best when he talks about biology (surprisingly, considering he is a physicist), and at his worst talking about physics. He is a bully when it comes to physics; he has a couple chapters, as I recall, where he goes on about how there can never be total certainty, yadda yadda, but then he gets to The Core Theory and he brazenly announces that, in one thousand years, the Core Theory will be recognizable in its current, 2016 form; he claims that it is not going to be tossed out, though it will undoubtedly be made more precise over time. What the hell happened to "we can never have certainty" and "everything human is subject to error and cognitive bias"?!?While this book is called The Big Picture, it really seems more like a bunch of snapshots rather than a single coherent image. Some chapters were just downright obnoxious to read, and I wanted to give up around chapter 20, but then it really picked up around chapter 30 and I began to really enjoy the book. Had the entire book been closer to the last half, I'd have given it a 5 star rating. Instead, I am giving it a half-way 3.5, between the 2-star beginning and the 5-star ending. But that is not to say that the last half is perfect! Oh, no; far from it. The last section of the book, in particular, I found fairly difficult to read. Not difficult in the e=mc^2 sense (which was somewhat the case at first, but he does a pretty decent job at explaining things), but difficult in the "oh god are you really going to get into the meaning of ethics here?!?" sense. Yeah, that's right: he jumps from physics, some history of science, biology, and ultimately to morality! I think this was the greatest mistake; here you have a decent book that is taking a good look at relatively objective science, and you end it with discussing deontology and consequentialism. I understand why, I just don't think it was the best idea.Still, in general, I wouldn't recommend against reading this book. There is a huge amount of information contained within a pretty small book, comparatively. He makes good use of thought experiments to elucidate otherwise more complicated issues in science, and offers a very masterful hand to guide the reader on the tour of the universe. It is a good book, but it is flawed nonetheless.

One must appreciate the enormity of this undertaking by Sean Carroll who is no doubt extremely knowledgeable in the sciences. His depth and breadth of knowledge in physics, cosmology, biology, and molecular biology cannot help but impress. His comfort with philosophical thought is similarly impressive, though increasingly it seems that many physicists have become philosophers, and many philosophers have become physicists. The book is a serious and scholarly effort to explain "The Big Picture." Each chapter is a sort of lecture, and the content must be appreciated for its accuracy and completeness. This book as a college course or series of courses for science and arts majors alike would, no doubt, be well worthwhile. Kudos to Carroll for this explanation of what is known, and how the knowledge of it can enrich human lives.It's hard to find a downside to this tome, though not impossible. I made the mistake, in my opinion, of "reading" this book audibly. It was read by the author himself. Even when I sped up the rate to 125% of normal, some of the chapters seemed to linger on forever despite the interesting content. My analysis is that Dr. Carroll should not have read the audible version of the book himself I should mention that I have read the paperback version of "From Eternity to Here" by Carroll, and it held my interest throughout.There's something about how Carroll speaks that detracts from his very good writing skills. The two most distracting features are his fairly monotonic delivery along with his natural tendency to end sentences with upward voice inflections rather than downward ones. I would simply recommend a hard copy or electronic version of the book rather than the audible version. The only other feature that I was mildly put off by was the arrogance that often crops up in books written by scientists who seem to believe that their current view of the world is the only view that is credibly possible. As most good authors do, Carroll assimilates his chapters so that they build to the punchlines at the end of the book in chapters 49 and 50. Those were good chapters indeed, though I was mildly amused that those chapters reminded me a bit of another, much lower-brow book, that took me only an hour to read, 'The Newstament".All-in-all, this was a challenging read and a highly educational one.

I wish this book had entered the popular consciousness to the degree that The God Delusion or Sapiens has. This is the first "big picture" book (it's a genre) that I felt articulated back to me what I already believed when it comes to to the big philosophical questions of epistemology, ontology, the mind-body problem, free will, metaethics and so on. All these subjects are tackled clearly and persuasively, but in this case I needn't little persuasion. This was for me the ultimate "reading inside the bubble" experience. It's not a productive way to read - it's worth challenging your beliefs with contrasting viewpoints, of course - but in this case it felt valuable. Carroll explains what I believe better than I ever could.Carroll rolls out a well-planned, carefully argued map from fundamental scientific approaches to knowledge (Bayesian reasoning, empiricism) through justifications of high-level models like biology and psychology, to theories of the nature of consciousness, morality and meaning. He names his philosophy "poetic naturalism", which is naturalism (that the natural universe is all there is) extended with the notion that higher-level conceptual models for the world are just as "real" as the fundamental theories of particle physics and quantum mechanics.I felt like Carroll didn't elaborate enough on his choice of of the qualifier "poetic" for his variety of naturalism. I guess what he was trying to find a word like "metaphorical" or "abstract" but with looser connotations.Carroll's tone is wonderfully warm, clear and generous. He introduces all the major philosophical schools of thought during his tour of its many subjects, and treats them charitably, giving them carefully written summaries explaining their strengths and weaknesses, because explaining his own views.This is a book well worth reading, especially if you'd like an approachable explanation of how scientifically-minded, skeptical atheist type people see the world, without the venom or haughtiness that can be grating in other popular books by such folks.Or, if you're just looking for a rich and enjoyable tour of some of philosophy's trickiest problems, and a compellingly 21st-century and clear-thinking approach to dealing with them, this is the book for you.

On OntologyWe all have a reason for being. For many, that reason sits below the surface of consciousness, chilling on a metaphysical couch, cracking open a beer. This reason operates in the decisions you make, no matter how aware you may be of its existence.For the philosophers out there, finding reason for being becomes systematized into an ontology, a formalized approach to purpose. Humanity divides itself in many ways. There are red ontologies and blue ontologies (in the United States at least); there are religious ontologies and areligious ontologies. There are consumer ontologies and conservationist ontologies. We’re pretty good at making systems that describe what we do.If I had to take a self-critical look, I would suggest my ontology orbits a narrative theological approach to life. I believe in the power of story to describe life and to give normative abilities to our daily life. I believe the narrative of Scripture provides an intriguing way of describing long-term generational narratives and purpose around life. It’s a good outline by which we can live, and if we take Pascal’s wager seriously, it’s also a no-brainer.Because of my ontological approach, I tend to avoid the typical faith-vs.-reason debates that have spotted our cultural map for decades. A culture warrior I am not. Even more so, I don’t even care too much about this relentless fight for truth. I believe in science, as a politician recently noted. I believe that science can unlock important discoveries that will benefit society as a whole. I don’t think a debate about our origins or where our environment might go does much for ontological purposes, especially from a narrative approach.On Poetic NaturalismAnd yet, I’m interested in hearing about ontologies that stray from mine. With The Big Picture, Brian Carroll presents an argument for poetic naturalism, an ontology that finds purpose in life, without relying on supernatural beliefs.An engaging and enjoyable read, The Big Picture spends little time fighting the culture wars. While I have a handful of small critiques about Carroll’s presentation of theistic views, on the whole I found him charitable to competing views. This book finds little in common with the Richard Dawkins militancy.“But there are biases on both sides. Many people may be comforted by the idea of a powerful being who cares about their lives, and who determines ultimate standards of right and wrong behavior. Personally, I am not comforted by that at all—I find the idea extremely off-putting. I would rather live in a universe where I am responsible for creating my own values and living up to them the best I can, than in a universe in which God hands them down, and does so in an infuriatingly vague way. This preference might unconsciously bias me against theism. On the other hand, I’m not at all happy that my life will come to an end relatively soon (cosmically speaking), with no hope for continuing on; so that might bias me toward it. Whatever biases I may have, I need to keep them in mind while trying to objectively weigh the evidence. It’s all any of us can hope to do from our tiny perch in the cosmos” (149).With The Big Picture, Carroll develops his argument for poetic naturalism. He dives deeply into a philosophy of science and epistemology, making the case for why science is the most rational approach to observing what we are able to observe and why the troubles with absolute proof matter little when you live your life based on principles of Bayesian reasoning.While this line of reasoning covers the “naturalism,” component, the “poetic” component is a little fuzzier. Carroll suggests the many examples of where we use various modes of communication and language to describe the same thing. A person, for example, is a rational being capable of autonomous actions. She is also a collection of molecules, which is itself a collection of sub-atomic particles. Both descriptions of the same thing are equally valid. Therefore, we have a poetic approach to the ways we describe our world.“Poetic naturalism sits in between: there is only one, unified, physical world, but many useful ways of talking about it, each of which captures an element of reality. Poetic naturalism is at least consistent with its own standards: it tries to provide the most useful way of talking about the world we have” (112).And yet, as I’m sure Carroll would expect, I remain unconvinced. If there’s one consistent element to humanity, it surely coincides with our ability to hold our beliefs dearly.On the Limitations of NaturalismEven though I affirm all of Carroll’s work and find his deep dive into the physical elements of our universe to be fascinating, I find his poetic approach and his naturalistic approach to be lacking.Of course, naturalism sets itself up to be limited.When I was taking a class on the history of the New Testament, I sat down with the professor during office hours to discuss the historical significance of the resurrection. Given the burden of proof for historical texts, I assumed the evidence we have points to a pretty strong case for what’s noted in the gospels. We know Paul wrote at least a few of his epistles, including 1 Corinthians and Galatians. These epistles point to a resurrection story and a confirmation of that start, nearly within a handful of years after the event. There’s nothing like it in historical texts.My professor walked down the line of reasoning with me, affirming me at each point. At the end, we agreed that the resurrection story emerged as early as 9 months after the supposed event. No other story in history can be traced as closely to the event it references.So did it happen? My professor says, “No.” When I curiously ask for an explanation, his response aligns with naturalism. The resurrection is an event unmeasurable by definition. As a historian, it would be irresponsible to suggest that such an event exists. We can only say that story emerged early. Not that it actually happened.This story points to my main question about naturalism. It constrains itself, rightly, to the measurement of the physical world. Likewise, by definition, any supernatural element in the natural world is likely immeasurable. Such occurrences would be unique if they happen at all. For this reason, they sit outside the realm of naturalism and many naturalists conclude against their existence.Let’s Be PoeticFor me, the poetic is an important ontological aspect to reconciling some of these potential elements of life. Simply suggesting that there’s nuance in life and that we make our own meaning, as Carroll does in The Big Picture, falls short for me. But of course, my worldview starts from a position of narrative theology.On the whole, The Big Picture is a worthwhile read. I enjoyed it and learned much about how naturalism can provide ontology for those who practice it. Recommended.Originally published at http://www.wherepenmeetspaper.com

The book cover doesn't lie. Carroll really does tackle the big picture, starting with the fundamental question of how to ascertain the nature of reality, to the origin and overall state of the universe, to the evolution of life, the appearance of consciousness, free will, and finding meaning in an uncaring universe. Throughout, Carroll's writing is lucid and approachable: these may be big ideas, but they can be understood.Some of the ideas to retain are:- There is no up or down in space. The reason we think "up" is so different from "down" or "left" is that we're very close to a planet that exerts a gravitational force on nearby objects. Likewise, there's no "before" or "after" at the level of quantum physics: you can swap a time axis for a space axis and the equations still make sense. The reason we think the past is so different from the future (or from left and right) is that we're very close to a point of very low entropy: the Big Bang.- Planets of belief: some beliefs naturally congregate: if you think that there's an afterlife for humans, then you likely think that there's an afterlife for dogs as well. And if you think that, then you likely believe in souls. Carroll calls these systems "planets of belief" (though perhaps an analogy involving a social network might have been better).- Poetic naturalism: this is the idea that there are many different ways of describing something that are true and, just as importantly, useful. It's true that a car is a collection of molecules obeying the laws of chemistry, or even as a collection of subatomic particles obeying the laws of quantum physics. But there are far, far too many molecules (or atoms, or fermions) to keep track of, so it's much more useful, and no less true, to consider a car as a collection of mechanical parts. What's important is that where they overlap, the different explanations be compatible.In the end, unsurprisingly for a scientist, he sees beauty and wonder in the universe, and hope in humans. What's remarkable is the way Carroll ties together all the elements of the journey into a coherent whole.

The book describes the concept of "poetic naturalism", the idea that there is a physical world that we can observe and, while we might not understand all of its workings, can build effective stories about it. The best stories match our knowledge of the underlying earth and don't contradict each other. The world is; through stories we bring beauty and goodness to it.A large part of the book is about creating a story that does not depend upon a supernatural being. It's a tour-de-force over the universe's origin and end, time, entropy (hint: it always wins), how life came into being, minds and how consciousness might have developed, free will and how we can define morals without leaning on the guidance of supernatural beings.It tells a story about humanism, the desire to learn about the world and how to update one's beliefs. In that, it is not anti-religious but rather anti-blind-dogma. It tries to understand life by naturalism, without a reason to look beyond the physical world while being open that something else might be going on. It caught me off-guard with the hint that even if you're open-minded you should over-value uneasy new stories as you will be subconsciously be biased and de-value the new theory anyways.In that, it is honest, the author's "confession" that he would like to offer an afterlife but cannot do this is telling. He offers an example, how lucky we are as group, that we have found each other in the vastness of space and immensity of time, for a short period (of ~3 billion heartbeats).. and to cherish this thought.He finishes up a bit bleary eyed, stating that the distinction is not between theism and naturalism, but that the important thing is to care enough about the universe to want to understand it. All lifes are different, some face hardships that others will never know. But we all share the same universe for a precious few heartbeats. The clock is ticking.One quarter into the book I thought that I won't finish and let it be one of the few unfinished books in my collection. Then it caught on. In the end, it landed in my "great books/reread" collection. Funny, how life turns out sometimes.

A well written book that (mostly) deals with Ontology in modern science. Sean carroll espouses a school of belief called Naturalism and adds his own ideas into it to eventually call it 'Poetic Naturalism'. Sean's belief is that even though the universe itself is (with an extremely high likelihood) governed by fully deterministic physical laws, it isn't very helpful to talk about different levels of reality using the same vocabulary of limited words and ideas. Different 'levels' of reality, such as microscopic and macroscopic worlds, consciousness etc all need to be investigated using different methods and different contexts. What is important is the nature of the investigation itself and here, Sean suggests the Bayesian approach, which is : Start with some prior beliefs about the nature of the world (theistic, atheistic, scientific etc), giving equal credence to all of them. Next, update your prior beliefs by asking the question, 'Given belief X is true, how likely is the world that we see every day?'. If the answer is something along the lines of 'not very likely', then reduce the credence of belief X and increase the credence of another belief Y that better explains the world as we experience it.As with most philosophical writings, aspects of Ontology, Epistemology, Ethics etc are discussed at length and often compared and contrasted with other belief systems. The writing is unpretentious and conversational and being both a professor of theoretical physics and a communicator of science, Sean speaks with knowledgeable authority and yet, never forces his beliefs on the reader nor ridicules other schools of thought (except perhaps the moral relativists).Irrespective of whether or not 'Poetic Naturalism' is your cup of tea, the book deserves a read because it deals with several deep questions of modern science, such as the Arrow of Time, nature of reality, Consciousness etc. I certainly had a good time reading it and pondering over the topics (and their consequences) myself.

I really enjoyed reading this book because it identified that science doesn't have all the answers but that there is no reason to assign super natural factors to the unknown. Our world is an intelligible mystery that will be uncovered through rigorous scientific inquiry in due time. While science can be used to explain our physical world, Carroll highlights that science is not a tool for developing morality. We want there to be objective solutions to our moral dilemmas in line with scientific discoveries or mathematical formulas, unfortunately that is not the case.
