Morality is constructed by human beings and we are responsible for what it means to be good. While it is unsettling to think that we are in it alone and that there isn't a super natural force to guide us, I feel empowered by the idea that humans can define our moral destiny. We can throw away dogmas and archaic rituals and adopt new systems of ethics combined with ancient wisdoms. We have the power to change for the better. I highly recommend this book to anyone interested in learning about reality and what it means to be human. Carroll elegantly summarizes the idea of Poetic Naturalism in the following excerpt. Enjoy!"Here is a different story. The universe is not a miracle. It simply is, unguided and unsustained, manifesting the patterns of nature with scrupulous regularity. Over billions of years it has evolved naturally, from a state of low entropy towards increasing complexity, and it will eventually wind down to a featureless equilibrium. We are the miracle, we human beings. Not a break-the-law-of-physics kind of miracle, a miracle in that it is wondrous and amazing how such complex, aware, creative, caring creatures could have arisen in perfection accordance to those laws. Our lives are finite, unpredictable and immeasurably precious. Our emergence has brought meaning and mattering into the world."

As an advanced level reader and rational thinker, I started this book to see how does poetic naturalism resolves the puzzle of current scientific knowledge which can tell us about the coherency of science from different fields. Yes, I was aware of the fact that dark matter and dark energy is still in the domain of mystery, we still do not know how do these "Dark" staffs fit in the story of current quantum physics, i. e., their nature is still inexplicable by the current knowledge of physics. But I was more interested in what Sean Carrol has to say about consciousness or volition. I was quite perplexed by the lecture of Daniel Dennet, who says, we do not have anything of "conscious" inside us, the 'self' which can define ourselves as individual may not exist at all, the self is our illusion, just a mere byproduct of cellular molecular interaction inside ourselves. I wanted to ask Dennet, I agree with you that there is nothing sitting inside ourselves which defines "us". But can we call that byproduct of cellular molecular interaction inside us as consciousness which gives rise to individuality? Is there a 'self inside us' or not? Obviously, the next question, is there volition or free will? I was thinking what Sean Carroll think about these question? If I understand him correctly, he suggests, despite these philosophical and or scientific conflict, we can consult/accept common belief until science becomes more advance to answer these. I do not think, his philosophy of poetic naturalism can satisfy mind with critical thinking. I am okay with learning yes or no, I am okay with accepting yes or no, but being a naturalist, I am not happy to make a compromise with a common belief. It is better to think, it is unresolved, we need to wait for an answer instead of making peace with a common belief. This book is a good science hotchpotch, which does not actually offer anything better than naturalism. The name poetic naturalism does not offer anything new.

Very readable exposé of scientific knowledge. It covers the same ground as many other books of the same nature, but makes the case for what Carroll calls: poetic naturalism. It's an attempt to reconcile science with our human experience. An attempt to make the cold facts and laws of science, without purpose or meaning, more palatable to us, whose lives are made up of feelings and values and strivings, of loves and fears and hopes. Carroll tries to resolve this contradiction by saying that our experiences are just as valid as physical explanations and descriptions of events, but on an emergent level. At the same time it's all completely reducable to the automatic behaviour of quarks and electrons. So in the end all our talk is still just, as he calls it, 'a manner of speaking'. A purely human way of talking about the elementary particles that behave according to deterministic quantum field theory. It's a worthy attempt, but to me Carroll never succeeds in bridging the gap. And he admits that when the chips are down, we just don't know, and it's a matter of choice. He employs Bayesian logic to argue that a completely naturalistic paradigm (be it poetic or not) is the most likely explanation for everything, but this is only true when you, as he does, assume right from the start that everything is ulitimately made of something called 'matter' or 'energy' or 'physical stuff'. When after all, everything is just a perception in consciousness. And we have no idea what consciousness is. It's impossible for us to step out of our own consciousness and see what is really going on. What reality is really like. Whether it's really impersonal and dead, or personal and mind-like. It's the same old conundrum of philosophy that goes all the way back to the Greek philosophers, and will probably never be solved.

Just finished Sean Carroll's book "The Big Picture: On the Origins of Life, Meaning, and the Universe Itself". The book describes what Sean Carroll call "Poetic Naturalism" which is his version of philosophical Naturalism. Naturalism as the author describes it is a worldview where "there is only one world, the natural world...there is no separate realm of the supernatural". The book then goes on to justify this position and attempts to explain the universe's origin, morality and meaning. This book essentially explains my worldview so I was very excited to read it. I've read one other excellent book on Naturalism by Richard Carrier so that is what I will compare it to. I will honestly say this book is incredibly digestible for a subject that delves into science and philosophy and THIS would be the book I would recommend to a beginner on the subject. Secondly this is a book I could give to a theist without any fear of them feeling insulted (compared to a book like "the God Delusion"). I would say Carrier's book "Sense and Goodness without God" is slightly more technical and more difficult to read. Two negatives on Sean's book is that I feel his chapters on the universe's origin left me wanting more. Chapter 25 Why Does the Universe Exist? is only 10 pgs. Chapter 36 jumps back into the subject when discussing fine tuning arguments but this is only 12 pgs. I'm used to reading entire books on the subject but luckily there is a nice recommendation for further reading in the back of the book. I also disagreed with Carroll on the Morality chapter in regards to objective morality but I'm biased by my early readings from Carrier. Overall this book is a gem that I will re-read and reference going forward and will recommend as a primer for anyone interested in Naturalism.

While heavy on hard science and physics, the main thrust of this book is philosophical and existential. Throughout, Sean Carroll provides a contrast between naturalist (atheist) and supernaturalist (theist) worldviews, citing human scientific knowledge and support for the former over the latter. That's not to say that he is hostile or demeaning toward religious figures. Rather, he meticulously presents evidence and reason to argue for the philosophy of poetic naturalism, which is essentially the view that human beings are thoroughly part of the natural universe, not special or separate from the indifferent and immovable laws of reality, and that it is up to us (collectively and individually) to determine what is meaningful and purposeful in our finite lives.Personally, as an agnostic/atheist who periodically struggles with an existential crisis, I was emotionally torn as I read this book. It's a fascinating and engaging work, chock full of information and insight worth anyone's time. And even though I do not believe in an afterlife, I pretty much constantly hope I am wrong and that some sort of eternity awaits us. With that in mind, I sometimes felt intimidated and a little "overlooked" (for lack of a better word) of Carroll's casual and blasé attitude toward the end of existence (both at the individual and universal level). I certainly didn't detect an ounce of hostility from the author, but as someone who finds contemplating existence and meaning emotionally difficult, I had a hard time digesting Carroll's matter-of-fact tone at points.All that being said, the final couple chapters do offer a freeing and compassionate bit of philosophy and (to a certain extent) advice that rounds of the book and a decidedly uplifting and energetic note.

A physicist trying hard to infer (Bayesian probability) everything in our universe through poetic naturalism - everything just simply exists. Started strongly with where author’s strengths lie i.e. laws of physics, Core Theory, quantum mechanics that explains how our physical world is constructed in both macro and micro level. Arguments started to get fuzzy when trying to explain how atoms and particles make living organisms - the straw that broke the camel’s back for me is when author implied photons and atoms can have consciousness. The argument that living organisms are merely atoms ended extremely dissatisfying. Without a solid bridge between physics and biology, the future arguments on philosophical questions like, why are we here, what is morality, what is our purpose, is there a higher being, just ended up flat and unsubstantiated.An overly ambitious book which tries to explain everything using our still limited knowledge of our world. Case in point, author’s recognition of the difficulty to reconcile between Core Theory and quantum mechanics while selectively broad-brushed how the existence of soul or higher being cannot be proven hence doesn’t exist. By trying to bridge the unknowns using Bayesian theorem, author subjects all arguments down to his individual bias that if something cannot be explained through laws of physics, it is not real.Furthermore, in a bid to denounce religion, felt to me that author is trying to spread his own belief - the poetic naturalism. Philosophising through physics without addressing human emotions is like colouring a rainbow only with black paint.

4.5 starsThis one wasn't an easy read. It started of pretty strong, not necessarily that much stuff I didn't know yet, but just making you actively think about the universe can be quite mindboggling. So I spend a lot of time while reading this imagining the size/age/etc of the universe and just trying to wrap your mind around the insane scales it operates in. Some chapters were definitely better than others, and sometimes he gets bogged down a bit too much in the specifics, and while those are definitely important, it doesn't really make for easy reading at times.I enjoyed the part where he explains why things like telekinesis, telepathy, etc are not really possible under the laws of physics as we understand them. It is a good way to make it very clear why all those people that claim to have supernatural abilities just can't actually have them.Some parts were explained very well and gave me some new insight into the workings of small (and large) parts of the universe. I liked the mixing milk into coffee example of explaining our current status in the universe and while I already believed most of the things that Sean Carroll Advocates, it's good for someone to articulate it better than I can.Overall I did really enjoy the book but part of it is because I kept getting lost in imagining the process of the universe expanding up until this point, and beyond, how it would be to observe this process happen. It's hard to put into words what exactly I think when fantasying about the universe but it comes down to trying to understand the size of astronomically large numbers, both in size and time.

I have to say it took me a while to figure out what Sean Carroll (research professor in the Department of Physics at the California Institute of Technology) was trying to accomplish in The Big Picture: On the Origins of Life, Meaning, and the Universe Itself. I suspect my prior expectations (that this would be a book about physics) led me astray. The book begins with the concept that objects can be described at different levels of detail. For example – you can describe a cat in terms of elementary particles (say superstrings) or quarks, or atoms, or molecules, or combinations of molecules (chemistry), or in terms of the cat’s structure (biology), or organs (physiology), or behavior (ethology), or physical distribution (evolution and biogeography), or interactions with the ecosystem (ecology). Which level you choose will depend on the property of the animal you’re trying to study/explain. He then discusses Bayesian statistics, the idea that the true state of the world can be expressed in terms of degrees of belief based on the available evidence. Of course, physics is discussed (Newtonian, relativity and quantum theory), before an excursion into the biological sciences and later into philosophy.  So what’s the point? Carroll is outlining the basis of a worldview based on our current scientific understanding of the nature of reality. That worldview is known as philosophical naturalism (or poetic naturalism, though I prefer the former phrase) - the doctrine that the natural world is all there is. Thus The Big Picture isn’t so much a book about physics as I was expecting (except to the extent that physics informs the discussion), but a book of philosophy.  The basis of this worldview lies in Carroll’s claim that “The laws of physics underlying everyday life are completely known”.These laws are encapsulated by the Core Theory, which explains the forces that effect all macroscopic, low energy objects. This isn’t to say that science has explained everything … there are many things that we currently do not understand. But that, the physical laws that affect our daily life (such as gravity, angular momentum and acceleration) are understood and that these concepts will remain valid 1,000 years hence. There are many conclusions that logically follow from this claim. For example, physics informs our understanding of the forces at work in the universe (gravity, electromagnetism, the strong and weak nuclear forces), thus we also know that telekinesis (the ability to move objects with your mind) isn’t real since it’s incompatible with known physical laws (or if you prefer a Bayesian approach, it has a likelihood of being true that approaches zero given the available evidence). In other words, for telekinesis to work it would have to utilize one of the known forces or would have to act through a force completely unknown to us at this time. Carroll is claiming that it can’t possibly be either since:1. If it acted through a force we already understand it could be measured and quantified scientifically. However, no such telekinetic force has ever been measured. 2. It could not act through an unknown force because we already know all of the laws of physics that makes up our everyday life. There can be no other unknown forces that act on human-scale objects.Therefore, telekinesis doesn’t exist.  You might ask … so what? No one believes in telekinesis anyway. Well, the same principle may be applied to other beliefs that are more widespread in society:Astrology can’t possibly be real. The forces exerted by planets distant from the earth are overwhelmed by the forces exerted by nearby objects. For example the gravity exerted by a person standing next to you is greater than the force of gravity that Mars exerts on you. Thus the position of Mars couldn’t possibly have any effect upon your daily life. Therefore, astrology is nonsense. I’m easing you into this, because this also holds true for more tightly held beliefs. Ready? Prayer doesn’t work, a god that interacts with the physical world doesn’t exist, there is no life after death, there is no absolute morality and life has no inherent meaning other than what you make of it. That wasn’t so bad … just like ripping off a band-aid. You’re now ready to put on your big boy (or girl) pants and face the world as it exits.  Of course, those who disagree with this approach typically claim that scientists assume naturalistic explanations a-priori coming to it through ‘belief’ or ‘faith’ in science that is indistinguishable from religious faith. But this is not the case. There is nothing inherent in the scientific method that excludes supernatural explanations. It’s just that no supernatural explanations have been found to exist. Thus scientists do not have ‘faith’ that philosophical naturalism is true (to have ‘faith’ is to believe without evidence). The data resulting from every reputable experiment done throughout all of history point conclusively to the fact that the natural world is all that there is. If you believe otherwise, all that’s needed is conclusive proof that the supernatural exists and the Nobel Prize will most certainly be yours (I’m not going to hold my breath).  In the latter portion of the book Carroll applies the principles of philosophical naturalism to the issue of ‘consciousness’ and ‘mind/body duality’, and concludes that the former is entirely consistent with the Core Theory, while the latter is not. Thus we may conclude that consciousness is an emergent property arising solely from the physical activity of the brain.  Carroll then discusses morality and shows that there is no external benchmark upon which an objective morality can be based. Instead, it is something we need to figure out as a society. To that end he proposes 10 Considerations (analogous to, but immeasurably better than the 10 Commandments) for constructing a consistent system of ethics (you have to admire his fearlessness).Overall, the book is good. Carroll has the intellectual breadth and depth to take on a big topic such as this (life, the universe and everything … what could be bigger?) and presents numerous compelling arguments that he backs up with scientific evidence. I will say that I found the book a bit dry at times as he argues for or against one philosophical point of order or another, but ignoring competing theories wasn’t an option and he manages, for the most part, to avoid becoming wrapped around the axle.

Sean Carroll's book is aptly titled: It does indeed cover the big picture of 21st century scientific and, to an extent, philosophical thought -- but that is both its strength and weakness.If you haven't read any books about quantum mechanics, the origins of life, emergent phenomena or normative thinking, then "The Big Picture" will get you up to speed. If you've only read one or two, Carroll's engaging and informative style will neatly complement your knowledge and fill in some gaps. But if you've read more than a few such books, or subscribe to Science News or other such magazines, "The Big Picture" is more of a rehash than a revelation.Then again, of course, there are always things to learn, and Carroll's ability to tease out insights is impressive -- though his use of the term "poetic naturalism" to describe his belief system is a little, well, poetic. The idea is that all there is to the world is natural sciences and material reality, but we describe it in many different ways, using different "stories." I think "narrative naturalism" would be closer to the mark, as Carroll's view of the world is much, much more prosaic than poetic.It also seems to me that Carroll is too dismissive of what has yet to be discovered, and much like the authors who have declared the end of history, or the demise of art, it seems arrogant and presumptive to assume that we've got all of the basics nailed down.Still, "The Big Picture" is a worthy read, though its value is inversely proportional to how many popular science books you've read before you start.

"When it comes to how to lead our lives, poetic naturalism has no fish to give us. It doesn’t even really teach us how to fish. It’s more like poetic naturalism helps us figure out that there are things called “fish,” and perhaps investigate the various possible ways to go about catching them, if that were something we were inclined to do."When this book is good, it is great. I did HSC Physics, and have read my share of physicist non-fiction(Hawking et al), and this was the first time I felt like I really grasped relativity at all. Carroll is blessed with the capacity to explain, and the book clearly and purposefully sets out the ideas. Combine with that his strong understanding of philosophy and comfort - no, joy - in combining the two and the book never ceases to be either thought provoking or readable. Carroll has ethics, and an approach to science which (mostly) lacks arrogance. He wants to share this, and he understands a dizzying array of knowledge.And if the rest of this review seems critical, it is in part because my expectations were so high. Carroll sold this as taking from modern physics, philosophy and neuroscience, bringing different fields together to pose a new approach. Poetic naturalism, however, turned out to be not-so-new, really, but rather the sane form of humanism: "1. There is only one world, the natural world. 2. The world evolves according to unbroken patterns, the laws of nature. 3. The only reliable way of learning about the world is by observing it." Now, I appreciate that in a post-Dawkins world, we now have to fight for a sane form of naturalism, one which is about embracing doubt and uncertainty, rather than hitting people over the head with fat evolution textbooks, but I guess I was still expecting something a bit more from this. Or maybe this, a powerful argument for a sensible approach that has done science well for centuries, is what we need right now. I can't fault Carroll for that.But the second quibble was just, well, Carroll's physicistness. Now, based on the above defined lifelong misunderstandings between physics and I, physicists may choose to ignore what I am about to say, but they should not. There is a certain parting from the observable world, into following perfect theoretical constructs that lead to highly non-intuitive, and more importantly, unprovable conclusions in the multiverse/string theory set. There is a set of assumptions here, ones which may well be right, but which could induce a little humility or at least acknowledgement that they *are* assumptions. Some physicists seem to live so entirely in the particle world, that they forget that the rest of it, the mechanical world, still exists. Caroll warns us about the head-spinnyness of understanding quantum entanglement, for example, but he does not acknowledge that this head spinnyness is because a lot of this still doesn't really make sense to humanity: the multiverse is a theoretical consequence of our current theoretical understanding, which assumes modelling can be extrapolated. I'm not saying it can't, for heavens sake I'm just a librarian, but the "certainty" with which string and multiverse theoreticians state their case exaggerates the extent to which we have a clue if we know anything at all. And sometimes, the way they dismiss disciplines rooted in observation and testing can be galling. And yes, I understand that no-one wants to phrase it like "we really don't know much", when there a bunch of pro-interventionist-god folk battering at scientific endeavour to accept explanations which have, honestly, long been ruled out as not taking us anywhere. But all knowledge comes from accepting diversity, uncertainty, contradiction: the possibility, nay, probability, of being wrong.The book felt like it spent so long arguing against idealist notions - and really, how many fundamentalists are going to read this? - that it had little space left to explore the lovely grey spaces, the potentials, in the bits of the universe that we can't yet see a clear coherance too.Carroll is disappointing here not because he is blind, but because he strays so close to the border: condedng with glee, for example, that time's arrow is a construct we have evolved to be dependent on (and possibly, hence, may never be able to disentangle ourselves from), that rather than there being nothing before the Big Bang, we just know that that is the point at which something we understand happened. But then, rather than exploring what possibilities this limitation might set up, he retreats back into certainty. Carroll speaks of the need to accept different ontologies to describe the world. That, for example, the heart is as real a thing as the particles it is composed of (the fact that we are even having this conversation tells you why physicists drive me nuts), and the language of heart, organs, body is as valid as that of electrons, etc. Yet he strays so close to a particle-centric view of who we are. The neuroscience is skipped over, focusing only on parts which mirror or imply quantum operations. He spends time dismissing the idea that being composed of particles denigrates our free will, that he does not tackle more interesting ideas about whether, if our decision making is diffused rather than centralised: if there is no central director in our brains, then can we be held accountable? Who is the entity that is responsible if we are multitudes? On a basic level, he used the example of "telepathy" to indicate how spiritual ideas can be disproved. But for starters, he's actually talking about telekineses, not telepathy, and secondly, he misses some interesting perspectives that he could have explored if he was talking about telepathy: 50 years ago, human didn't understand how powerfully we communicate through pheronomes. This isn't "telepathy" in the sense of the existence of a particle force we didn't know existed, but it was an explanation of a powerful form of influence we exert invisibly on each other. There is a lot yet to discover about how those pesky particles work in us and around us, and sometimes the ways we come to those answers might be a diverse paths - observation, explanation, testing, refinement can come from a myriad of disciplines.But for all those quibbles, I'm pleased to be on the same path as Carroll. This feels like my kind of thinking, and my kind of place. And seriously - grateful for the insight.

Great book.Great communicator. I came to know about Sean Carroll by watching one of his debates with William Lane Craig and by some college lectures available on YouTube. I decided to give him a try as soon as I came to know about this book, because he seemed to me like a guy that stands out from many atheist scientists and speakers out there. "The Big Picture" presents a completely naturalist point of view of the universe; the most evidence-based view we can come up with so far. Its scope is impressive. He discusses many things, from theories in classical physics and particle physics (the basic underlying reality of the universe), chemistry, biology, neuroscience, psychology, social sciences, history, philosophy of religion, morality, epistemology, metaphysics, metaethics, etc. Overall, it is a well written book and in my opinion, pretty accessible for the layperson. It does not include complex equations (like Krauss' "A Universe From Nothing" does), except in the Appendix. I often found myself saying: "that is an awesome and clever way to put it!". You will find comments against traditional arguments for a god or a "supernatural" reality (about the ontological, cosmological, teleological arguments and religious rationale in general, including superstitious thinking about quantum mechanics.So, if you have the chance to read one popular science book a year, I really recommend you to try this one.

The Big Picture by Sean Carroll describes his view on how the universe works, how we fit in and what we should do as human beings. Knowing him as a theoretical physicist, it is no surprise that the standard model of elementary forces and particles plays an important role in this tale. The Core model describes all relevant interactions on earth already for decades, and all measurements confirm the validity of it. Caroll goes then on: since we know the forces and interactions of matter and energy, there is no relevant place for something else. Ergo, bending spoons with your mind is not something that the model allows, knowing what we know. Also, the presence of a soul, a creater or a heaven is not necesary to describe the universe. Taking this as a model, Caroll starts to spend more attention to the philosophy side: Without God, what is the reason we exist, how does a social construct look like of atheist. What is conciousness, experience and how does that materialize from the brain. I am taking very big steps here, Caroll works down many details and elaborates on many aspects more.I was more interested in the hard science part of the story, but the moral part is certainly interesting, although it took significant more time to digest. I admire the detail in the book by quoting all kinds of philosophers and scientist on the existential questions. I think I will remember the final words: "3 Billion heartbeats, the clock is ticking" 4 stars

This quite ambitious book covers a lot of ground, generally to provide an explanation of the universe and life. It was really well written. At times he would dive really deep into physics and discuss very complex science. I found myself losing interest at times because of the depth he went into. But other times he scratched an existentialist itch I have. He spent a lot of time on philosophy and explaining to theists much of the error in their logic, if they're trying to use any. He argued in Bayesian terms why the scientific explanation for how the universe exists is the best and only reasonable explanation we have. I would definitely recommend this book on that basis, for someone interested in the scientific vs. theistic look at the universe and the meaning of life. Carroll discusses looking for meaning in life without the theist point of view, and that moral codes are a human invention, not something handed down from a higher being. He expresses many humanist thoughts. He calls himself a poetic naturalist, a term he coined. For example, he does not believe there is no free will (which could be explained in multiple ways, one being that down to the molecular level we are just atoms that are trained to act in the way evolution has created us), rather his poetic naturalism says this "no free will" is not a useful way of talking about a phenomenon that we seem to use quite freely everyday.

It is all the rage lately for theoretical physicists to write books for a lay audience. It seems that the physics of the very large and very small are interesting because they are so counter-intuitive (curved space-time, black holes, quantum entanglement, etc.) Here is another entry and Carroll also has opinions on everything else so this book covers a lot of ground. There are 50 chapters and one (big) equation (in the Appendix). The theme that runs through the book is the idea that we can talk about lots of interesting things at more than one level. In the same way that a gas is a collection of atoms obeying the fundamental laws of physics but also an emergent phenomenon obeying Boltzmann's law we can talk about consciousness in terms of atoms and sub-atomic particles in the brain, or as psychology. This idea gets overused and sometimes seems to beg the question (e.g. There is no such thing as free will at the atomic level, but there is free will at the level of personality and intentionality.)End of review - beginning of rant."They" is a plural pronoun used to refer to more than one of something. It is not a PC device to avoid the issue of gender. I grew up using "he" as the pronoun for a person of unspecified gender and I have learned to use "he or she". Fine, I understand the point. But I'm not willing to injure the language and when Carroll uses "they" in this way it hurts my head. Does anyone care that this makes me uncomfortable? I didn't think so.

“The Big Picture”, is certainly just that, an awful lot of ground to cover. My first thought was that Sean Carroll had bit off more than he could chew and at best he would cover the big picture with a thin frame. But I was wrong and he covered the topic with museum quality displays of knowledge. It was a wide ranging look at the current state of affairs not only in the hard sciences such as physics but as much as possible in the soft science of human behavior from neuroscience to social relations. He seems to want to propitiate all points of view and makes you think that at different levels of reality it is okay to use different vocabulary that does not translate well from one level to the next. But he always comes to the conclusion that the naturalist explanation is the true description of life. No matter what topic you’re couching you argument in, ultimately all descriptions can not violate the core theory of quantum mechanics. He wants us to realize that the world and universe are impersonal and as a structure built from the impersonal substance of the cosmos we are free and obliged to define ourselves as we see fit during the nanosecond of our existence in the vastness of time. The book is quite enjoyable to read because Sean Carroll has an encyclopedic fund of knowledge and you never feel that you’re being short changed in any topic he covers. And if you’re a naturalist as Sean is you’ll find the book quite reinforcing.

I had a hard time understanding so much about this book. I thought this was going to be about the science underlying the universe, but all of it was used a reason not to believe in God. I am not a subscriber to any particular religion. In fact, I go back and forth whether even God exists, and if It does, what is his/her nature. So I felt tricked into reading an atheist's primer on why God doesn't exist when I thought I going to focus on the science of the Big Bang, the universe, evolution and such. In the beginning there was a lot about quantum mechanics, which I want to know more about, but just went right over my head. I don't blame the author, since it's been about 20 years since I've been in a physics class, and quantum mechanics is not known for being easy to understand. I will probably end up re-reading that portion. Then there was a lot about philosophers and using science and logic to talk people out of believing in God. Then at the very end he summarizes everything, part of which says "it takes all kinds", stating that he doesn't want to be at odds with religious people, but essentially says that they're believing a lie in order to feel better about their life. Guys, I just wanted science. Not an 420+ page essay trying to convince the people who AREN'T READING THIS BOOK that they're wrong. If he focused more on science, and less on an argument, this would have been so much better.

The writing is very clear and straightforward, and builds to a discussion of some of the deep questions, but there is little here I haven't seen before, and his answers are pretty conventional for a scientist. Regarding qualia in particular, he finds them a useful way of talking about the world, but his thesis is simply that of Democritus: "by convention sweet, by convention bitter, by convention color; in reality, nothing but atoms and the void." There's little more frustrating than an author who can clearly see and explain what the hard problem is, and then goes on to act like a functionalist explanation dissolves the question with some talk of emergent properties. You have to at least address why some complex computations in the brain are accompainied by qualia, and others not! He wants to allow the reader to meaningfully talk about concepts like god and spirit, but denies that they have any properties that would make the universe different than one in which such things didn't exist, such as an afterlife.His discussion of the arrow of time and entropy was the most interesting part of the book for me (he really is exceptionally good at explaining scientific concepts), but saying that everything stems from the universe starting in a low entropy condition felt rather like pushing all the things that have to be explained into one pile and saying "nothing needs to be explained except the one pile." Sure, but it's six million feet high.

[This review originally posted on my blog, www.Jill-Elizabeth.com.]Today we are heading into the land of theoretical physics, by way of the philosophy of, well, everything… My review copy of The Big Picture was graciously provided by the publisher, Dutton (Penguin Random House).I have always been captivated by science – quantum theory, physics, chemistry… I find it endlessly fascinating to learn how things work, to read origin stories, to think through new theories on how and why the world works as it does. I’m trained as a lawyer, by way of studying philosophy. At first blush, the interest and the formal study seem miles apart – the hard science of facts versus the soft “science” of supposition and truth-seeking (in all its myriad forms). But if you look a bit deeper, you quickly realize that the areas are actually exceedingly close – especially when it comes to much modern scientific theory and fields of study like string theory, chaos, and quantum mechanics. There is a lot more truth-seeking of the philosophical, theory-of-everything, school in science than I think many people are comfortable with; scientists and science enthusiasts like facts and experiments, they live and die by replicability and reliability, and those aren’t words most people normally associate with law or philosophy. Not so Sean Carroll, as is exceedingly evident in his latest, The Big Picture.The book is subtitled “On the Origins of Life, Meaning, and the Universe Itself” and believe me when I say Carroll covers all of them adeptly and without dumbing anything down. He is a much-lauded theoretical physicist, and it is not difficult to see why he’s received the accolades he has – even if you, like me, are an amateur (and armchair) science fan and theoretician… His theories are well presented and clearly laid out. That’s not to say they are simplistic – they definitely are not. They are adroitly presented, with historical support and background, and are written in language that can be challenging to unpack but the unwrapping is part of what made the book so enjoyable for me. Too many “popular” science books are written in an overly simplistic fashion. I realize that a lot of theoretical science is exceedingly complicated; removing that complication isn’t necessary for laypeople, deciphering it is. And Carroll is a master at translating high-concept physics into accessible packets of information. You may need to reread some of the descriptions to truly grasp their layered complexity – I certainly did. But the chapters and ideas are presented in manageable, European- rather than American-sized, portions so rereading did not require as much effort as it may sound like it would.Sprinkled throughout the book are philosophical as well as theoretical underpinnings for the ideas that are presented. The philosophy student in me loved these connections; I think they bring a lot of depth to the discussions of modern science theory and certainly inform the debates about reality and purpose to a level of sophistication I found fascinating. The explanations of these theories are crisp and clear and I think should be manageable to those for whom they are new. At the same time, as with the scientific presentations, the philosophical analyses and explications are high-level enough to hold the interest of people familiar with them. Carroll is quite adept at providing a narrative that balances expert- and introductory-level concepts. That is no easy feat – it’s rather like tap-dancing among land mines, one false step and the whole thing is blown to hell. There is nothing worse than reading a scientific or technical book and suddenly realizing the author has left you in his dust – or, equally irritating, to realize he has suddenly started talking to you like you were a simpleton. No fears about either here – the book reads like a conversation with your favorite professor: you feel rather proud of yourself for holding your own, because you know you’ve been treated like an intellectual equal even if you both know that you certainly are not…I recently read an excellent book about the history of lobotomy (Patient H.M. by Luke Dittrich). Early in The Big Picture, I found myself in an “aha!” moment about memory and causality and our experience of time. Carroll was discussing how we perceive time in the context of past, present, and future, and how our memories and the concept of entropy are a way of understanding possibility, time/causality, and interrelationships. [NB: I realize that is a vastly oversimplified statement that also manages to sound rather confusing, even knowing what I meant to say, but please forgive it – is necessary for the point I’m trying to make that I say something, and I’ve rethought and rewritten it several times and this is the best I can come up with, despite its limitations…] The gist of my realization had to do with the multiplicity of options available in the future, and how the presence of those unknowable possibilities renders our experience of the future distinct from the present or past, where the options are vastly reduced – the connection to the lobotomy patient being that he lost his ability to form memories, which meant that for him, there were just as many possible options to the present (and even the more recent past) as to the future, which led me to a fascinating inner debate about what that meant for his experience of time.I realize this seems like a rather odd tangent; it is not meant to be. What it is meant to illustrate is the wide-ranging applicability of the theories and ideas Carroll is laying out in his new book. Within just a handful of opening chapters, the vastly big-picture theoretical physicist book was already not only interesting but also relevant. The book is full of such “aha!” moments, covering as it does everything from memory and causality to the history of the universe to our interrelationships and experience of love and life. This isn’t a book for the faint of heart; as I’ve stated, it takes effort to read, especially if you want to truly grasp the intricacies on exhibit. It is effort that will more than repay itself though. I suspect I will find myself coming back to the theories and concepts laid out by Carroll on a surprisingly frequent basis – after all, the big picture, by definition, touches on everything…

Let confess up front that I enjoy reading deep science books even though I don't fully understand all the topics in them. But with each one I read, I come to understand just a little bit more about things like black holes, quantum mechanics and string theory, just to mention a few that still go well beyond my layman's comprehension. But I do read them to the very end, not skipping over any pages when the going gets rough. In this awesome book that talks about so many deep topics from the 'big picture' perspective, I found many that are getting a little clearer with each book read. In his closing chapters he even gets into naturalism and his history of attending church in his boyhood days an dhow he evolved into his beliefs today. But that was just one of many very mentally challenging topics that I recommend to your reading. Well presented, this is a very interesting challenge to one's mental abilities facing everyday science that is so deep in its richness as we are learning more and more each year of the mysteries of our universe(or it is 'cosmos' - I still don't know the difference or even if t here is a difference in those two terms).see this and more than a hundred other organ donation/transplant related books - many with my personal reviews - at http://www.trioweb.org/resources/book...

Great book. For the first time I see a top-notch physicist that is also well versed in the philosophical tradition. He does a very good job of putting (almost) everything in a coherent framework. Physical laws, knowledge itself, life, nature of mind, consciousness, morality, existential dread, and many other important topics.While I was reading the book I remember him regretting on social media that he didn't make clearer connection between his "poetic naturalism" and the notions of Pragmatism. It was sort of funny because just a couple of days earlier I was precisely asking myself that question. His description of poetic naturalism seem to fit very well what I had learned about American Pragmatism and was wondering why he had chosen to come up with another term. In any case, I think it works well for the general audience.I think it is a great book since most popularizers of science tend to be quite ignorant of the limits of science or just (unknowingly?) sweep under the rug the fact that we experience the world not as a bunch of atoms, but as human beings and we cannot escape the big questions, where science is of limited help. Nevertheless, we can still be rational about the pursuit of answers. I think many other scientists, like Dawkings or deGrasse Tyson, should learn from Carroll.

Thought that this book was exceptionally well done, giving the reader a lot to think about and ponder regarding the larger questions of life. Building upon the historical relationship between science and philosophy the author does an amazing job of building the case for poetic naturalism as the optimal lens through which to consider the world as it relates to recent development in physics. Appreciated the authors ability to explain technical scientific concepts such as quantum mechanics, thermodynamics, and the chemical and biological processes of life in a way that was comprehensible by a non-specialist such as myself. The idea of different ontologies or world views is a very useful way to talk about the linkages and segmentation between different opinions and camps of thought, touching on the notions of internal and external consistency to try to approach the quest for finding truth in this world. This book taught me a lot about both the scientific principles that underpin our world and the way that philosophers across different time periods and disciplines have acknowledged and addressed these quandaries. Finally I appreciated the practical bent of the considerations being discussed, with the focus often on how to integrate these ideas and arguments in to the way that you live your everyday life, to make the most of your 3 billion heartbeats.

Every few years, a scientist, typically a physicist, so overwhelmingly satisfied with the state of affairs in sciences, sticks their neck out to claim that the theoretical scientists are largely done theorizing and if the current theories fail to shed light on your little corner of darkness, there must be either something wrong with you or that patch of stubborn darkness is emergent (it must be getting rather crowded under that metaphorical rug!) if not entirely illusory. In other words, for example, if the consciousness doesn't quite jibe with the physical sciences in your opinion, stop messing around with the already Godly quantum mechanics to bail you out and definitely don't go around throwing in the salt of duality in any of its flavors to the perfect soup of the Standard Model to suit your palette. What such all-is-fine-with-sciences apologists won't tell the reader is that every bit of theoretical physics is under suspicion at this very moment.Sean Carroll no doubt does as good a job as can be done to explain the big picture using the established science. The book is worth reading just for that alone. This way when you come up with your own theory of consciousness, you can first hone your arguments against this inanimate book before embarrassing yourself in front of an animate audience.

Sean Carroll seems to get a lot of the big questions right and is an excellent communicator allowing the reader/listener to draw these (or other) conclusions himself/herself. From the Everettian interpretation of quantum mechanics over the relationship between disciplines (poetic naturalism) to spot-on sober considerations about the existence of God, life after death, etc. (spoiler: these ideas just don't fit data).Perhaps because of the high standard, I was surprised on two smaller topics. First, Carroll only weakly supports utilitarianism as the overarching framework for a moral philosophy based on some easily-refutable classical objections, including the utilitarian monster, how to measure happiness, etc. I (and others) acknowledge these as potential problems but not as weaknesses since they hit with at least the same force in other frameworks. Also, utilitarianism fits well into the general Bayesian approach of the course. Add a loss function for happiness, and you are good to go!Secondly, as a neuroscientist, I found a few things inaccurate on that topic (too much functional localization), but nothing as to change the overall... picture... of a both fascinating and incredibly enlightening piece of work from Sean Carroll. I strongly recommend this (audio-)book and other works by Sean Carroll.

If I could give this 10 stars, I would because compared to many of the 5 stars I give, this book far exceeds them all. Sean Carroll (one of my two favorite scientists with the same name) has an uncanny knack for explaining highly difficult concepts...like quantum physics...in a way that an average person with only under graduate classes in physics and math can understand. This is more than a book about physics (though I would argue what more does one need than physics???). It's also his thoughts and analyses of philosophy and sociology. I learns so, so much from this book. I bought both the audio book, narrated by the author, and the hardcover volume (well, okay, I didn't actually buy the hardcover; it was gifted to me by Anderson's Book Store where I gave a presentation on Women in STEM...thank you, Anderson's!), and I highly recommend that if, like me, you like to do house chores and enrich your mind simultaneously which you can do with the audiobook. Then, when you get a section which strikes you as particularly brilliant and poignant, you can pause the reading, take out the hardcover and mark that section for easier access later. This book made me think deeply in a way few other books have, and hence my wanting to give it more stars than Goodreads will allow. Have I mentioned that I'm a huge nerd? And proud of it.

If you are a fan of the tv series 'The Big Bang Theory', imagine Sheldon Cooper writing a book on the universe, the emergence of life, and examining questions related to faith. That's 'The Big Picture' for you. I say so because just like Sheldon Cooper, Carroll also looks at the world from a physicist's perspective. Carroll discusses various strands on universe, the arrow of time, quantum physics, complexity theory and the emergence of life, and finally moral philosophy. He is a gifted writer with the ability to explain complex topics in most simple ways. However, my problem with this book is that it tries to do too much at the same time. Especially towards the end, Carroll makes some honest observations, it keeps the reader wanting. If you are already exposed to science writing, you may enjoy this book. If you are not, I'll suggest you to first read specialised books on universe, on quantum physics, on the arrow of time (Carroll's own earlier book), on complexity theory, and then maybe come back to this book. Even so, if I'm interested in the philosophical musings of a physicist, I would go to Alan Lightman's 'The Accidental Universe' that I found more accessible and intellectually fulfilling.

This is a well written and thought provoking book that gives the reader theories on many Philosophical arguments. The theories focus on almost exclusively a scientific perspective and the answers that Sean Carroll provides are centered around poetic naturalism. Although this is a great read with an easy to understand writing style, I find the book pretty one sided. The author states how much we don't know about our universe and "The Big Picture", yet uses the theory of poetic naturalism to confidently answer these questions. It is great to read about different theories, however I find the theory to be stated too confidently. For example, the author states how much we don't know about our universe, but then states with certainty how naturalism and science can almost completely explain the universe. I am not saying this is a bad thing, if you believe that naturalism is without a doubt the answer, this is the book for you. The author is a very good writer, however if you are looking for a book that details a broader spectrum of theories and ideas, this is not the book for you. This book is definitely worth reading in order see the universe's questions answered from a perspective of naturalism.

First few sections, pretty decent. All downhill from there, especially in the audiobook. I really wish the author had not chosen to read his own book, as any respectable narrator would look up how to pronounce words in fields that are not their own. Not Dr Sean Carroll! His mispronunciation of reasonably common biological and philosophical terms was jarring and unpleasant, making me doubt his knowledge of the fields. In terms of the content of the book: also pretty boring. Nothing novel coming out here, just a materialist who appreciates a good story naming their worldview "poetic naturalism". The philosophy included is the sort covered in intro courses and the first couple weeks of a philosophy of mind course. The biology is poorly covered and the author even has the gall to suggest students are scared off of biology due to terminology directly after pronouncing adenine wrong and not explaining at all the naming conventions of enzymes he's discussing. Maybe somone who knows no biology or philosophy would enjoy this book. I pushed myself through the audiobook because it was easy listening given I knew all of the material except some of the modern physics. Wouldn't recommend to any scientist or philosopher.

So many different disciplines and topics are packed into this book. Philosophy, metaphysics, quantum mechanics, general relativity, Core Theory, morality, ethics, and psychology are all included. I think the overall topic is poetic naturalism, of which Carroll is a proponent. Carroll's writing is to be commended for ease, flow, and use of analogies that make sense. A large part of the book is about how to connect our descriptions of the quantum, classical, cosmic, and human levels of reality. How does our description of fermions and bosons also describe a table, the motion of planets, and human emotion? The quantum world just does not jive with our everyday experiences so how can they both describe reality? Carroll takes the reader on a journey through each of these realms from the smallest to the largest to us humans. The last two parts of the book then delve into consciousness, thinking, and meaning. He touches on religion, morality, ethics and all the other seemingly nebulous aspects of being human. I enjoyed his view on these philosophically difficult questions. I am not sure if I am completely sold on his explanations but they are solid, well thought out, and convincing.

I was looking for a philosophy book written by a scientist and I have to admit I couldn't have landed on a better book.The book is easily readable 50 chapters, each dealing with a specific question or scientific law or phenomena. First half of book deals with science, mainly particle physics, thermodynamics, some biology and chemistry, which provides building blocks to explain higher order and complex entities. It moves towards philosophy, and culminates with commentary on consciousness, free will, and morality. Although the author doesn't admit he is an atheist, his stance is to explain everything using his philosophy called poetic naturalism, leaving some of questions about soul, consciousness, etc tentatively answered - they are the entities that evolved as things became more complex and it depends on the way one chooses to describe things - as human as collection of atoms. Author's tone is gentle and language kind (unlike authors like Steven Pinker who goes ballistics towards anything they disagree with), but the content might still annoy people with religious bent. Memorable quotes from the book:“The purpose of life is to hydrogenate carbon dioxide.”"We are star stuff which has taken its destiny into its own hands.”

It's one of the most thought-provoking books I have ever read. Reality is composed of two things: the natural world and inner states (caring, meaning, purpose, etc). The twist is the inner states are ultimately physical states as well, thus part of the natural world.I would be curious to see a theist's response to the writing; something more substantial than "faith" or "belief." I have a counterargument, though it cannot be assigned a high credence.This is the crux of Carroll's viewpoint: Bayesian reasoning. From empirical evidence, the natural world came into being and trudges along without any external, sentient forces guiding it. Human beings are part of it, but we add flavor and color to the universe by our capacity for caring, yearning, and loving. These emergent inner states we have are no less real just because they ultimately result from impersonal laws of physics.That's Carroll's view anyway. Read and decide for yourself. As Carroll puts it: "if our goal is to understand, we are on the same side."This book is probably best for those curious about naturalism, and wish to know its deepest merits.

The Big Picture is about exploring the nature of reality by encouraging a “poetic naturalism” point of view. There are three ways of describing the nature of reality:1 - The deepest most fundamental description. Understanding the particles their properties that make up the universe at the most basic level.2 - “Emergent” or “Effective” descriptions. These are the macroscopic views of the universe. A “ship” instead of “a collection of atoms”.3 - Value descriptions. Right and wrong, morality, goals, beauty. These are descriptions that science is less capable of describing.This is a big science book in the spirit of Carl Sagan’s famous book. Sean Carroll asks big questions and uses science to answer them (after all, he is a theoretical physicist), but he accepts the limits of science and our current understanding of the universe. But it’s more than just science; he takes the poetic naturalist’s view that you can talk about the nature of reality without having to go down to the most fundamental quantum mechanical descriptions. There plenty of room for philosophy without contradicting our understanding of the fundamentals.It’s a fascinating, sprawling book. It seemed a bit too broad as I was reading it, but after it percolated for a few days I appreciate how comprehensive it is. This one will still with me for a while and I can see pulling it off the shelf and thumbing through it regularly.

Covers how to think about the world. He argues for poetic naturalism. It is essentially naturalism which states that the world is only made of stuff that obeys the laws of physics. The poetic part refers to our different ways of talking about these collections of atoms. If you take a gas chamber as an example. It only contains individual atoms and air molecules. At the atomic level, there is no such thing as temperature or airflow speed and direction. These concepts only make sense when describing the system at the macroscopic level. The author argues that these higher-level descriptions are not wrong due to not being based on the core theory. They are the best way to describe the emergent phenomenon. It would not be convenient to give a daily weather forecast talking about atoms, fields, and forces.The same idea can be extended to beliefs, thoughts, emotions, people, and consciousness. People are just a collection of atom obeying the laws of physics. Does it make sense to saw people make decisions? The author argues that it does since we appear to do so at the emergent level of human beings but not at the atomic level.

Very strong and concise overview + high-level breakdown of contemporary physics, translated into straightforward English prose. The continued focus on Bayesian reasoning was appreciated--and as someone who's spent years studying Computer Science, this was familiar terminology that helped ground the argument for me. But I've also been reading pop-science books for most of my life now, and didn't feel like there was anything tremendously groundbreaking or mind-bending here. /start_opinion/ Carroll's strength as a rigorous, and detached analytical/scientific writer, also holds him back from adding just a *bit* more flair and bravado that would make this work truly memorable and, well... more exciting. /end_opinion/There's a lot of ground covered here, and Carroll does an excellent job as both writer and teacher, but I guess I was expecting something a bit more mind-expanding, (or even a bit scientifically radical) based on the title. I'd almost look at this like an introductory textbook, as much as a pop-sci beach book. It manages to work from both angles, but I also wish it was more focused from only one.

I picked up this book after listening to a Sam Harris podcast where Carroll pointed out the flaw of Harris deriving an ought from an is, which kind of underpins his whole shtick. The lack of an objective scientific grounding for morality is something to deal with, something that needs discussion and for which secular people are thirsty for knowledge. Carroll is a good grown up voice for this task. As promised by the title, Carroll covers a lot of territory. Rooted in naturalism, "a philosophy of unity and patterns, describing all of reality as a seamless web," this proved a good reader in cosmology, the core theory, complexity, and to an extent philosophy of mind and moral philosophy. Carroll presents a compelling strategy for talking about how you go from quarks and quantums to what is right and wrong. Astrophysics is nicely wed with evolutionary theory here, with lines resonating. "Our anatomy reflects the accidents of our evolutionary history," applies almost metaphorically to all forms of life, of space and time.

Caltech theoretical physicist Sean Carroll a done a superb job of connecting the known rules of base reality, quantum field theory (the very small scale) and relativity (the very large scale), with the human scale that we experience, and ties a big red bow on the *big* questions that have kept philosophers up at night for millennia. Really. Finding meaning in the existence of the universe, life, consciousness, morality, prescriptive ethics, free-will (or lack thereof) and the finality of death can all be inferred through Bayesian reasoning, and Carroll introduces the concept of "Poetic Naturalism", which is essentially useful ways of talking about the world at different levels at the same time according to their appropriate domains of applicability. This has huge implications because although the fundamental laws of physics don't describe things like chairs, people, time, or the rules of basketball, they do exist in the sense that they are useful ways of describing our macroscopic reality, and as such they are knowable.

This book wasn't quite what I expected, as the most recent book I've read by a physicist was Brian Greene's "Fabric of the Cosmos", which was a detailed account of some of science's most difficult and fascinating problems.Carroll's "The Big Picture" steers more in a philosophical and metaphysical direction. The discourse was certainly interesting, but not quite in the mind-blowing way that Greene's book was for me. I was already familiar with most of the topics covered by Carroll, but there were still some new and interesting ones: coarse-graining, emergence, Laplace's Demon, etc.This is a wonderful book if you are interested in learning more about the philosophical implications of physics. I think it would have been better for me to read Greene's book after reading this one first. "The Big Picture" is much more foundational, which is perhaps why I felt that it was underwhelming.Still, I will definitely be checking out more by Sean Carroll, because I love his ideas and he's always an interesting podcast guest.

Well worth a read to anyone with an atheist world-view, or even just for the concise summaries of some very big ideas.The core theme of the book is what he calls "poetic naturalism": the idea that the universe is deterministic but that that shouldn't necessarily stop you believing in the concept of free will. The author talks through some pretty heavy stuff: the origin of the universe, quantum physics, the evolution of sentience, the afterlife (or lack of one), moral philosophy, and more; and explains how poetic naturalism is consistent with what science tells us about the world.The scope of this book is immense and the subject matter is mind-meltingly dense at times, but he has a way of writing that makes things understandable to a layperson. (The only part that completely went over my head was the description of the core theory of quantum mechanics which forms the appendix--something he admits is grad-level physics.)I can see myself re-reading this, and probably getting even more from it the second time round.

Poetic naturalism is at the heart of Sean Carroll's ambitious effort in this thoroughly interesting book. As explained toward the end, his movement from a self defined "believer" and grandmother following churchgoer to a non-believer was a gradual one. What the "Big Picture" sets out to do is to reconcile his way of seeing the world as propelled by unseen and unfeeling forces with the feeling and seeing world we believe we inhabit. I found the first parts and the last parts most enjoyable. The middle parts bogged down in the sciences a bit for me. Core theory and the quantum realm could have been treated much more succinctly. But the more philosophical parts on morality and logic are most enjoyable and enlightening. My interest here though no doubt stems from my own background in philosophy and my own identity as a non-believer. The physics majors out there are likely to feel the opposite.

This is a book I wish I read as the first book when I was in college. Would be a great gift to my younger self. Sean Carroll goes deep into fundamental questions. What is the universe? What is time? What is life? What is existence? What is consciousness? What is value and meaning? Where do we come from? All of these questions are being addressed using scientific approach, empricism, and skepticism. "The universe is not a miracle. It simply is, unguided and unsustained, manifesting the patterns of nature with scrupulous regularity. Over billions of years it has evolved naturally, from a state of low entropy toward increasing complexity, and it will eventually wind down to a featureless equilibrium. We are the miracle, we human beings. Not a break-the-laws-of-physics kind of miracle; a miracle in that it is wondrous and amazing how such complex, aware, creative, caring creatures could have arisen in perfect accordance with those laws. Our lives are finite, unpredictable, and immeasurably precious. Our emergence has brought meaning and mattering into the world. " - Sean Carroll

This work addresses the nature of reality and the meaning of life...hows that for big picture questions? I can not pretend to understand Quantum Mechanics and the Core Theory, which is presented in probably the most digestible form possible in this work. My brain, possible due to age, can not absorb this material (and it takes up a decent portion of the work). I was far more receptive to the issues revolving around Morality and Ethics, and the author did a great job of explicating important considerations especially if you have left behind the presumed insights of religions. This book does a better job than most in addressing issues that always seem one arms length beyond my reach, and I am happy to have read the book. But I still would like to find an explanation of Naturalism that does not make me want to just go have an ice cream sunday to make me happy and return me gently to earth. Maybe I will have to wait for the Youtube version.

Carroll takes us through Poetic Naturalism, a philosophy that has a hierarchy of stories that we tell ourselves. Some uniquely emergent to just human-level domains of applicability and others fundamental to the inner-workings of the universe that should not be called out from their capability where their is little insight to be gained. We can tell ourselves numerous stories (the poetic in poetic naturalism) that do not need to be tied to fundamental physics but that, with rigorous reasoning can still help us to understand the conditions of consciousness, meaning, free will, morality, and love. Carroll does not write prosaically like Lightman, has fewer novel concepts than Deutsch, and the philosophy debates he has with the Moral Landscape of Harris fall flat, but he tells of a compelling big picture that is intellectually honest and usefully pragmatic where mystery, physics, and research intersect.

A thick (over 400-page) book with the mere ambition of explaining the "big picture," as in the title. So well written that I found it easy to read a chapter or two at a time. I learned a lot, tho' certainly not retaining every detail. And while the author is explaining the universe & the nature of reality, he is also deftly skewering religious beliefs, that is, any beliefs in anything that is not material. Quite a contrast to the furious attacks of writers like Sam Harris & Christopher Hitchens! Part One: Cosmos, includes his approach to the universe, what he calls "poetic naturalism." Part Two: Understanding, & the remaining four parts are Essence, Complexity, Thinking, & Caring. On the way, we pick up tidbits like entropy, quantum mechanics, the "core theory," emergent purpose, crawling into consciousness. Etc. etc. :-)

The topics that a book could tackle don't get any more interesting than the ones discussed in this book: Who are we? Why are we here? Why is there life? What is reality? What is consciousness? Why is there something rather than nothing? Sean Carroll provides a brief (relative to what I'm assuming is the vast length at which he could have answered these questions) summary of what we know up to this point regarding these big questions and many more, plus what we don't know, and what we are still looking for. The reading requires real concentration, and though he's writing for non-scientists, there were still a lot of concepts that I don't think I'm going to grasp. But even the most difficult concepts spur wonder and thought that are endlessly fascinating, and give me perspective, humility, and vast gratitude in my presence and part in the universe.

Sean Carrol is now one of my heroes. The Big Picture brings together nearly all types of intellectual thought (there's nothing mathematical that was new to me) - science, philosophy, logic - and shows perfectly how each on its own cannot define reality. Together, and with good-faith effort on the part of the thinker, they describe reality while translating it into something humans can make sense of. Hence, the perfect title of the book.It's truly beautiful. We don't need magic or fantasy to feel wonder. There's no need to ascribe some overarching purpose or meaning to existence as a whole. We exist. That's all that matters. Reality is what it is and it's up to us to ascribe meaning and purpose to our own individual lives. Theoretical physicist, Sean Carroll, couldn't have ended the book any more perfectly or beautifully:"Three billion heartbeats. The clock is ticking."

meh ... a few warrning sings for this Gentelman-There is nothing new in this book, that we woudn't have know already for a couples of years.-He tries to force his belives about the world and reality as science facts, rather than admit we have no clue and our understanding is not enough yet to make conclusions.-Awful argumentation style, that has no common sense or logic in it, He attempts to decribe subject for whole chapter from science perspective, than all of the sudden at the end of the chapter we have conclusion or statment made by this gentenmal, but he forgot to add it's only his belief about this subject, you haven't proof or disproof anything Mr. Sean, sorry -Book gets tougher to read when the author exceeds of area of his expertise, he should rather stay in just in physic, that the most interesting part of the book.

Really well written. I didn't totally agree with everything that was posited by Poetic Naturalism, but as a Cognitheistic Panthiest I certainly agreed with 97% of it. Not sure how someone without a scientific background would relate to it, but the basis of the core theory and how it relates to "All your thoughts on God" seemed very well expressed. The rest is just me not agreeing with mainstream Physics. I don't believe the superposition is real - I think it is an artifact of our measuring system. And although that wouldn't change the equations we use it in, it does have an impact on the future of the Universe, the origin of Dark matter and ultimately the essence of Cognition as the natural order of the Universe. Very thought provoking and was quite addicted to the next level of his discussion.

I finally got around to reading this gem. This is my first Sean Carroll book and he writes with such an agreeable ease, almost like you two are having coffee while he explains quantum physics to you. The chapters are short but are packed with good quality subjects to chew on. I highly recommend this book to anyone, but especially people like me with no real background knowledge, no extensive background knowledge anyways, of physics or anything quantum. He makes a great case for poetic naturalism, that this life is all that there is, so it's up to us to give it meaning and purpose. No afterlife, no behind-the-scenes ultimate string puller. Just the awesome laws of physics and the ways of talking about it and the grand emergence of us humans and the meaningful ways we can make sense of reality. All in all, a fantastic read.

this book goes deep. Not easy reading in many respects but it will challenge your thinking about such subjects as the meaning of life and the Universe. To me it is more about philosophy than science, but it very effectively links the two into a collaborative association. Fair amount of theology included as well. In my opinion, a very badly needed book that makes a valiant and mostly successful shot at explaining how we come to know things and to find meaning in that knowledge so science can become more than just facts and figures and incomprehensible jargon that, quite frankly, turns a lot of people off. As a biologist (actually ecologist) I found the book to be an important perspective on trying to link so many different views into a unified thought "ecosystem." Highly recommended and well written book on the meaning of existence.

Having read Richard Dawkins, this book proved to be a very great companion to the things I learned from the former. What I most enjoy about this read is the scope of information it brings to light, while telling the story about us Humans in such a way that is not only insightful, but brings verifiable facts into play in such a way that is not dumbed down. Of course one can always make the argument against this type of science and dispute it’s validity... however the author invites us to expand our minds and offers counter arguments against his arguments so that one can have both sides of the science to determine what it is that they should, or want to, believe. But like Richard Dawkins, if you take the belief that these science based facts are not true it is really hard to defend against them as the author points out the flaws in the arguments against them. Very compelling read, insightful and full of fascinating information that broadens our understanding of what it is to be Human.

Rather than chronicling the development of the universe from the Big Bang to the present, the author embarks upon the rather daunting task of showing how the current laws of physics, known physical forces, quantum mechanics, and the Core Theory are sufficient to explain everything (at least within the applicable context of this universe). Additionally, he tackles questions of origin, faith, self-perception, morality, and consciousness from the scientific perspective; maintaining an objective view and relying on the aforementioned laws, forces, and theorems to explain as much of these subjective topics as possible. And somehow, he manages to do so in an engaging and conversational tone, enabling the non-particle physicist to actually digest and enjoy this near-500 page book without suffering an aneurysm.

The Big Picture is a wonderful coalescence of science and philosophy, the stitchings of which provide edification and calibration to the human condition.Though Carroll’s scientific descriptions may lack the clinical splendour of predecessors Feynman and Sagan (but let’s face it, they’re tough acts to follow), his inquisitive ardor has fashioned an ecstatic read nonetheless. The bounty of truth eclipses illusion. Life is beautiful not in spite of but because of its transience. Meaning can be constructed with rationality, dignity and grace, unadulterated by the absence of a deity. With the publication of The Big Picture, Carroll has contributed a worthy verse to the naturalist rhapsody, echoing the sublime sentiment expressed best by our old pal Charles Darwin:“There is grandeur in this view of life.” fuck yea there is, charles.

Very interesting and educational. Carroll employs an incredibly wide range of scientific and philosophical concepts and theories, beginning with the microscopic/atomic levels of the universe and progressing to consciousness and morality in human begins, to essentially argue that the universe and humanity do not require any external/divine origin in order to exist and keep existing. On that same note, Carroll himself remains very respectful to all other beliefs, and to theism in general, considering he’s writing from a naturalist perspective. Ultimately, he concludes that human beings themselves are the miracle: the fact that “such complex, aware, creative, caring creatures could have arisen in perfect accordance with [natural] laws” is a miracle in and of itself, which I found both beautiful and hopeful.

Sean Carroll goes a long way to explain how several existencial questions can be understood in light of the current scientific understanding, and in this way provides an accurate "way of talking" (his poetic naturalism ontology) about our mundane experiences and how they fit into the bigger picture (as put in his title). I've been following Sean's lectures for a while, and it always amuses me how he manages to address these subjects in a very simple and straight forward way, extinguishing the "wiggle room" that is often used by people who misappropriate scientific vocabulary to reach invalid conclusions, specially in regards to supernatural phenomena, life's complexity amidst a chaotic universe and the role of quantum physics in our everyday lives. A must read for anyone who enjoys the wonders of a naturalistic view of the universe.
