MediocoreSomeone who tries to be neutral between atheism and theism, believer be noon believer in anything more that physical reality, but kind of fails to do so. It shows in subtle way the author is inclined towards a certain belief and nudges the readers towards that.The topic - inconclusive, lacks direction though the TOC is made really impressive ( selling point). It's like a philosophical lecture without an objective.Fair attempt to merge science with spirituality but falls short, probably due to a degree of biase, or lack on understanding it limit of knowledge or experiencetowards anything spiritual. Simply put noon believer.Definitely a lot of good points and learning to take away though in parts.Not something I would like to refer again or read another one of the author.

This is an ambitious book in which Physicist Carroll describes his philosophy of "Poetic Naturalism". Unlike many of the books by modern physicists in which the author espouses strict reductionism, claiming that we'll be able to deduce all knowledge from the laws of quantum physics, Carroll recognizes the existence of emergent phenomena and the importance of looking at problems at the appropriate scale. He demands only that they be consistent. The book was strongest in the first 2/3, where the focus was on science, and faltered a bit when he ventured into consciousness, free will, and morality, and finding one's purpose. It seems he couldn't make up his mind whether his objective was to present his philosophy or to debunk theism and he got stuck somewhere in between. Regardless, it was a good, thought-provoking read.

After having set the book down a good while to finish my designation for work, I've finally completed Sean Carroll's enthralling exposition into life's most relevant issues. From life's meaning to consciousness and evolution, Carroll delivers an educated, thoughtful response to all of these different fields of human inquiry. I'm a Christian theist. Carroll's book has given me much to think about, not so much in not thinking God exists anymore, but about how I now better understand the other side's position. I hope to learn more so that I am better able to understand the naturalist, to converse with him, and ultimately to eloquently share why I think the way I do. Great read. Can't wait for more.

The science was quite fascinating and he obviously has that part down, however he blatantly misses the mark in his arguments against God and his role in the universe. I️ am not writing this review to get into a debate with the atheist scientists in his camp, but I️ have to stand and say there is a place where pure science and pure religion are one. God’s ways are not our ways and we don’t understand all the mysteries of the universe and the creation yet because God wants us to live in this fallen world by faith. He does want us to strive to understand its workings and learn as much as we can but don’t be so full of yourself as scientists to think that you understand it all because of what you can see and understand at this point.

This is a very nicely written book. It's about many different things, but in a nutshell I would say that it is a pop physics book, but written from a philosophical standpoint. He mainly writes from a standpoint of poetic naturalism, which is seeing the physical world in a naturalistic way, but also knowing that there are many different ways to tell each story. You cannot describe someone by knowing every atom they are composed of. Things are much more than what they are composed of. He goes through the book talking about the meaning of life in a cold universe with quantum mechanics and core theory, but still being able to find purpose. It's a great read overall and filled with physics and philosophy.

When I first heard about this book, not long after it came out, I figured I would no doubt like it. Like many other books I want to read, it sort of got pushed to the back of the line because I had so many other things to read...then, it came out as a $1.99 BookBub deal on Kindle, and I got it!I can honestly say it was even better than I'd hoped. Dr. Carroll deftly weaves together a "big picture" from across the various scientific disciplines of quantum mechanics, biology, chemistry, evolution, neuroscience, behavioral science, and adds a thought-provoking and fascinating (to me, anyway) philosophical inlay of human consciousness. For those who enjoy reading about everything science and philosophy, you won't be disappointed!

An exceptional read. Given how much Sean Carroll bit off, I found it to be very manageable and insightful. Tieing up all of our current worldly understanding into a neat package is no mean feat and one which I appreciate greatly. Importantly, I found that I gained a more succinct perspective on each of the topics in the book, each adding to the overall picture.The quantum mechanics almost always goes over my head, but every time it does I become more familiar with how weird and unintuitive it is. The description of the emergent properties of macro-scale systems explained a lot for me, especially in the way that poetic naturalism gives credence to the reality of useful concepts. A very good reminder of the power of taking a step back and marvelling at it all.

For me, Sean Carroll hits the sweet spot with this book - he gives a compelling narrative that eases you into some of the scientific principles to be discussed, but then he doesn't spare you the detail that you need to at least partly grasp the complexity and often the astonishing magic of the topic at hand. I came away with several new areas for future reading to dig deeper, and with a great sense of perspective for what we know about universe, and how much there is still to know (much of which we will probably never fully uncover).It's a book to give you wonderment, and to whet the appetite for more. Thoroughly recommended to anyone looking to explore the big questions and not afraid to reread a paragraph occasionally to be able to absorb some serious detail.

I received an ebook advanced-copy of this book in exchange for an honest review. Thank you to NetGalley and Penguin Group Dutton for providing me with this copy.The Big Picture brings together physics and philosophy to consider some of the big questions of life, the universe and everything. This could have resulted in an unwieldy lump of a book, but this 480-page beast has been broken down into well thought-out sections and manageable chapters which walk you through Sean Carroll’s thought-process.The book seeks show how our scientific understanding of the universe can explain how the universe came into existence, how life was an inevitable consequence of the laws of physics of this universe, and how consciousness is an inevitable consequence of life. But it is also more than this; it is a thesis for independent and critical thinking, and a reassurance that a meaningful and moral life can be found within (and perhaps could be a logical consequence of) a naturalist state of mind.The book begins with the cosmos, which seems like a fairly intimidating place to start, given its size and complexity, but is in fact a gentle introduction to the tone and style of the rest of the book. It takes us through the fundamental nature of reality, where Carroll shows how ontology affects observation. This leads neatly to a definition of what Carroll calls “Poetic Naturalism”. From here causality and the arrow of time are defined and explained, not only in terms of the words we use to describe them, but also in terms of physics, particularly at a quantum level. This is an important foundation to build as it leads to an explanation of entropy and the second law of thermodynamics, which together explain both memories and causes, and thus how human beings experience space-time.From this foundation, the book progresses to a section entitled “Understanding”. This explores the different ontologies we employ in order to make judgements about information and form opinions about the things we believe to be true. Carroll presents a number of ontologies, followed by analyses of their virtues and disadvantages. The tone of analysis is logical and evenly weighted, ultimately leading to a conclusion that the Bayesian approach is the most even-handed.The Essence section explores what we know about the universe, explains the quantum realm and how to interpret it. A definition of the Core Theory is the presented, from which Carroll describes what we are made of, what the world is made of, and why the universe exists. From this deep physics, he then discusses scientific understanding of the body and soul, and death.Complexity explains the intricacy of the universe as an inevitable outcome of the laws of physics. Entropy, the force which takes the universe from a state of order through a gradual decline into disorder, is described using the example of cream being mixed into coffee. This lovely visual example shows how as an extremely organised state of particles (the cream sat on top of the coffee) is subjected to entropy (stick a spoon in and give it a quick stir) the coffee particles and cream particles become arranged in a complex and beautiful way before the process completes and the cream particles are evenly distributed within the coffee particles. From here it explains how the universe as we currently observe it, in all its wonderful complexity and harbouring of life, is a natural state to find ourselves in as our universe transitions from extreme order into disorder. You can probably tell – this was my favourite section of the book.Part five explores consciousness, and the enigmatic structures that are our brains. This naturally progresses into a discussion of artificial intelligence, and explores the question “could a computer become conscious?” and “how does consciousness arise?” Carroll doesn’t claim to have all the answers, but does clearly explain what science knows so far, where the gaps are, and what can reasonably be inferred until further scientific knowledge is gained. In seeking to address the questions surrounding consciousness, Carroll acknowledges that ultimately we are all built from inanimate particles, and postulates on various trains of thought that might prove useful directions of enquiry.The final section moves away from physics, and sits itself firmly in the realms of philosophy. Carroll asks how we can find meaning in our lives while existing in a universe that keeps moving without apparent regard for our existence. He gives his views on spiritualism, and how those who prefer to live by a naturalist ontology can find meaning and fulfilment. This leads to a discussion of the various incarnations of the Ten Commandments, and Carroll’s offering of the Ten Considerations. With these in mind, he seems to suggest, we can find both personal fulfilment and make the world a better place.The physics in this book is fascinating. I enjoy reading popular science books for the joy of being introduced to new concepts. The Big Picture covered a lot of concepts I had read in other books, but shed new light on them, showing the consequences of those concepts on the world we observe.It was heavy reading, requiring a lot of focus in order to keep track of the sheer volume of information and to fully understand each argument and concept. In a month where my reading time has been fragmented and brief, keeping up with this book was hard work. It definitely requires a time commitment, and I think would be more easily read over a shorter time span. It is an intriguing read, and has left me with plenty to think about.

Like his namesake Carroll leads me through the rabbit hole towards my realisation that I'm a so called 'poetic naturalist' myself.What I like most about this book that there are no presumptions and every supposition is held to the highest scrutiny. Through these discussions the facts and fiction of many stances on different subjects are compared and it's hard not to come to the same conclusion as Carroll. Of course this is where the books leads you, but the book feels sincere and very conscientious.I'll probably have to reread this many times to catch all the subtleties, but in general I can recommend this book to everyone.

Carroll sets out to do what I considered nearly impossible: a comprehensive, concise and approachable description of known physics and the role it plays in every layer of the human experience. He succeeds and does so in a way that will have you asking more questions from a position of the sheer joy of discovery. If you want a well-articulated, poetically masterful explanation of naturalism and the state of the natural sciences, I can think of no better book to start (and for most end) on than this one. This is not just science, it is a testament to the power of philosophy to guide the human path towards understanding the universe and our place in it.

Sean Carroll was already one of my favorite authors. The Big Picture secures his standing among the elite. His writing is clear, lucid, and full of examples and models that leave me feeling relieved and satisfied with my understanding. His humor is evident throughout, as are his passion for science and love for those in his life. I read this as an ebook on loan from my local library and regret that I now don't have a copy of my own. I found myself saving quotes that I can refer to later. I'm not sure I've ever done that with any other ebook on loan. I highly recommend reading this book ... But you might want to get your own copy.

Goodreads' blurb describes the book well. I think I understood almost all the physics, since much of it was a review for me. He tries to make it all accessible. He makes a good explanation of how science can account for everything around us and about us, though he relies on saying that consciousness is an "emergent property" of what physics and biology have learned. Not a detailed explanation of how it emerges. No supernatural intervention required, as I believe. He says it leaves us to make our own purpose and morals. I basically agree with that, though much is made for us by culture. I recommend doing that work in n open-minded community.

The universe is not a miracle.It simply is,unguided and unsustained, manifesting the patterns of nature with scrupulous regularity. Over billions of years it has evolved naturally, from a state of low entropy toward increasing complexity , and it will eventually wind down to a featureless equilibrium. We are the miracle, we human beings. Not a break the laws of physics kind of miracle; a miracle in that it is wondrous and amazing how such complex, aware, creative, caring creatures could have arisen in perfect accordance with those laws. Our lives are finite, unpredictable, and inmeasurably precious. Our emergence has brought meaning and mattering into the world.

From the Big Bang to the meaning of human existence - The Big Picture is a perfect guide to the profound philosophical and scientific issues of our time. Chapters like 'Cosmos', 'Complexity', and 'Caring' touched delved deeply into the nature of the physical world, the origins of life and species, and the foundation of morality, reason, and meaning. The author's style is clear and filled with sharp reasoning and worthwhile examples. This is a book that makes you think and isn't afraid to introduce questions without giving you all the answers. I walked away with far more knowledge than I began this book with.

Although the description of the book never attracted me in the first place, Sean Carroll is such an excellent writer, in particular an excellent writer of popular science both in book and blog form, that I decided to give it a whirl. Well, I'm not quite sure who the target audience for this book is, but what I am certain is that it is most definitely not me. The first 3+ hours of the audiobook consistently lulled me to sleep with Intro to philosophy 101 observations on causality and the terminology employed to discuss it, both elaborated at great lengths, to the point of losing patience and no longer giving a fig about what the rest of the book is.

This was an excellent book. Sean Carroll introduced Poetic Naturalism and showed how it was compatible with the natural world we see and how theism isn't. It's heavy on physics as you might expect from a theoretical physicist. But I had no trouble keeping up. Though, if you fancy yourself up on quantum mechanics, the Appendix A will be a treat...Importantly, Carroll doesn't just show how theism isn't compatible with the world we see, but offers how one could live a moral, well-lived life without theism. It's fairly long, but broken up into digestible chapters (roughly 30 min each in audio format). Which is good since it gives you lots to think about.

This was a painful, yet rewarding read. Sean Carroll did an excellent job making his case for Poetic Naturalism, but I wanted something more objective. I think he’s a brilliant thinker, just disagree. His willingness to have his cake and eat it too is painful to listen to as someone who has made their peace with determinism. Compatiblism to him is basically don’t be a dick atheist determinist. That should go without saying, but I can understand that he is speaking from a well established context. We need to move towards more honest explanations of human behavior for very real reasons. Sean doesn’t seem in a hurry to reconcile fantasy and reality, but I don’t blame him. It’s hard.

A lot to take inThis is a really precise and well written science book. It is immensely interesting and definitely a book that will blow you mind with the scope that it covers. I’ve read many science books and have yet to find a mainstream one that offers a clearer insight into the Second Law of Thermodynamics that this book tackles so successfully. That alone is worth reading the book. Having said that, it covers so much more from quantum mechanics to Bayesian Logic. I also really just appreciate Carrols love and fondness of Science. It really shows in his writing and I think a lot of people would really GET something out of it, even if it’s not what you intended to get.

Here is a great secular overview of the world. Carroll start with the most fundamental problems in philosophy of asking "what exists" and "how do we know". He then writes about the start of our universe, basic building blocks of matter, strange phenomena in quantum physics. With a solid ground in physics, he builds on how life could've arose on Earth, and how all living things have evolved through natural selection. Then we tackle one of the most puzzling problem we have yet encountered, the problem of consciousness. He surveys major struggles in philosophy of mind and finally presents a humanist worldview on ethics.

Mostly an Attack on TheologyI was disappointed that this book devoted so many chapters just to attacking theology. Write about what you know, Sean. That’s why I bought the book. What animus drives you to delve into dismissing theology? Your basic argument throughout the book went like this: Science provides a better explanation of origins than does religion, so religion should be dismissed. You make the mistake of discussing theology only through the eyes of physics. Just like I wouldn’t want a Jesuit priest to explain quantum field theory, I don’t want a physicist to explain theology.

Interesting and somewhat understandable for the casual listener with a marginal scientific background (nothing since undergrad classes). Here's what I don't understand - how a brilliant, well-educated scientist can claim to be open-minded, that there is a possibility of multiple universes and that there are laws of physics that may be amended (much like Newton's law of gravity) in the future can claim without equivocation that there is no possible way that there could be life after death. And of course anyone who doesn't agree just doesn't get it. Still, it helped me understand the Universe just a little better. It's readable even if I didn't agree with everything.

I love carrol's style (both as a speaker and a writer) so i always enjoy his work, but this book felt like it was missing something as far as content goes. It's called the big picture for a reason; it touches on a wiiiiiide swath of human knowledge and discovery over the centuries. But because of that it can't go into much depth on any particular topic. For some readers this might be enough but i found it a bit lacking and had to force myself to power through it at times.Bottom line: it's a good primer on the history of human thought and has Carrol's usual easy-going style, but it might leave you wanting more.

Thomas bit off quite a lot with this book, and I'm so glad to have read it. I understand the reality of our universe far better now than I did when I started reading- in particular Bayesian reasoning felt revolutionary to me. I had a guide through the reading, someone with a far stronger physics background than me, and that created a unique experience where this was as much a conversation between the two of us as a read. I was less excited about the meaning and philosophy portions of the book, where I felt I had already read better explanations elsewhere.

A lot of words, but...Well worth the effort to read. The rational mind is arguably one of the greatest developments of all time, right up there with life, stars and spacetime itself. The author expounds a philosophy of life based on the scientific method and its results and prospects for the future. In the course of the discussion, many deep questions are addressed and information integrated from many areas of science. The book is breathtaking in its scope and very appealing in its conclusions. It just isn't fun to read.

Long science book which reads like a philosophy book . The author fails to engage the reader in many of the book chapters. This book is broken down into six sections: Cosmos, Understanding, Essence, Complexity, Thinking and Caring. Eventually the author delves into science after a long discussion on Philosophy.  The end of this book is a personal narrative on moving from Christianity to naturalism. This is definitely one of the better parts of the book. This spiritual discussion could stand out as it's own book.

This book was so good that after I listened to it for free, I bought a kindle version so I could read it. The author is a Caltech physicist who is writing about the intersection of science and philosophy. He does a great job of talking about how science works and what's knowable,provable and observable. He's pretty clear that science is never settled. He also talks about consciousness, life and even zombies (as part of Turing tests). Makes me wish I was smarter. The quantum field theory discussion is hard to follow on audio, that's par of why I bought the print book. This was really fun.

Carroll tackles all of the biggest questions from the perspective of poetic naturalism. Somehow addressing complex topics of physics and various metaphysical ideas in a sensible and sober application of language that simplifies as it defines. The chapters are short and digestible, Carroll's sentences sharp and clear. Instead of feeling baffled by the language of physics I felt comfortable and eager to follow Carroll through his demonstrations and precise arguments for the compatibility of a pluralistic and complex human reality based in a soundly physical universe.

I believe this is a decently written pop science book. Although I found it a bit too boring. Not my type, I guess. Bought it at Irvine Borders Noble and expected really high to the book, as I was captured by its short chapter by chapter pace, and most of the topics such as the origin of universe and us are also my interests. However author focus too much on philosophy and too less on science. And his repeated statement of poetic naturalism is really too boring and also annoying. I read the final 130 pages on a three hour sztobj flight and didn't get much from it.

This is Sean Carroll's attempt at doing Cosmos. It's ambitious and all encompassing in scope. But instead of being a well-respected scientist's insight into the wonders of the universe, it's a well-respected scientist's ramblings on religion. He repeatedly sets up straw men telling the reader what religious people believe and then shows using his philosophy of poetic naturalism how deluded those religious people are. It's evangelical atheism, and it's not very well done. And if that weren't enough, he misexplains entropy so much so that I wonder if he really understands what entropy is.

Wow. A tour de force performance as Sean Carroll shows us how are understanding of physical reality, developed over the last 100 years (mind blowing stuff itself), relates to heady topics like free will, consciousness, religion, living a good life and morality. Although not explicitly an atheist book the explanation for why their is no extra soul or spirit (even in consciousness) was so well articulated that you just kind of sat there and said, "Oh yeah. Of course." I found all of the book to be very accessible. Brilliant!

First...best 4 page explanation of the quantum mechanics equation in the appendix.Second...outstanding list of other books to read on a wide range of subjects.Last...The book is about naturalism (aethism). Carroll is a brilliant mind with a philosophical competency. I am impressed with his willingness to lay bare his most personal interpretations of God and the physical world. I don't know that I agree completely, but I do appreciate his point of view. A complicated, but well constructed world-view consistent with his world of quantum mechanics.

This book had less science and more philosophy than what I expected. Now that's not surprising because science cannot assign meanings or moral judgements on the things it discovers. Sean does a good job of addressing the big questions of life from a "poetic naturalism" perspective, as he calls it. Essentially, it's a rational and scientific outlook on life. One thing that I didn't like about this book is his constant bashing of a 'straw man' God. It gets tiring after a point. We get it, God is not an old man in the sky.

🤯🤯🤯🤯🤯🤯🤯🤯🤯🤯🤯There's soooo much to unpack in this book. I absolutely loved it. This was kinda like reading a series of books but if you combined them into a linear narrative all linked together with philosophy and mathematical physics. Think of harry potter told from Hermione's point of view. (Harry Potter and The Order of the Cosmic Phoenix.) It was amazingly diverse and told in a very relatable way. Highly recommended for anyone who wants to really challenge their thoughts about where they fit and how it's sometimes easier to understand 42 than life, the universe, and everything.

Reading this book has given me one of the most fulfilling experiences I've ever had while reading a book. As non-fiction, popular science books go, it is wildly rewarding with its insights into the nature of reality and the underlining systems and worlds that define our existence. I can't recommend this book enough. It's extremely rare and maybe even unprecedented that I finish a book and remark: "wow." But it's happened for me just now and maybe it will for you too.

A mind-blowing, fascinating read. It's also pretty heavy shit to process. While your average Joe can understand it, if you're as average as me, you might need to take a breather between chapters or re-read some pages/sentences to make sure you're really grasping what's being put in front of you. I found the balance between science and philosophy pretty refreshing and I'd recommend this book to anyone that thinks they've the chops to tackle the material inside.

Carroll covers all of the most important current scientific and philosophical topics -- origin of life, quantum physics and gravity, consciousness, the meaning of science and life, the standard model of particle physics, and even why telekinesis and other paranormal crap can't exist. He does it in eloquent, calm, peaceful and ultimately undeniable prose. The title "The Big Picture" is a perfect title for a perfect book. This is exactly what the world needed. Carroll is my new hero.

it was ok. hard to follow the several explanations described buy minutae detail to prove a point. it does answer a great wuestion: how to find a purpose and meaning in a universe that does not have one? we make it ourselves. we are made of the universe and using our higher state of conscience, we take any form of energy, convert it to good energy, and release it back. whether it be a conversation, a friend in need, a stranger asking for help, a career choice. in that way we find happiness.

This book is a beautiful portrayal of the science and factual evidence of how our universe came to be. Have you ever wondered why the Universe is the way it is? Or how something happened? This is the book for you. Psychologist Sean Carroll writes with ease as well as a precise understanding about the complexity of our Universe. If you'd like to have a greater understanding about our Universe this is the book for you.

Amazingly thorough and wide idea coverage. A great physics & poetic naturalism book - I have never seen quantum mechanics as well/simply told (besides Feynman, which is a very high bar). Well put together Sean. My only suggestion is to question more deeply our purpose in the world, even if the purpose of the world itself is a bad question. I wish he'd more deeply discussed the implications of a single system experiencing at so many perceptive levels.

Though dry at times, this book is clearly the work of a well-intentioned, highly intelligent individual. It leaves the reader with well-summarized science, interesting philosophical exploration, and earnest intent. There are many, many bookmarks in place after this first read; this work warrants at least a targeted second pass to glean all the pearls.Would be 5 stars if not for the long dry spells between excellent sections of work.

As one of the many collections of sub-atomic particles fumbling around the cosmos searching for meaning, I found “The Big Picture” to be an excellent, thought-provoking read. Traveling solo through Europe with this book for companionship only helped to reinforce the very important ideas contained within. If you consider yourself a naturalist, or tend to wax nihilistic, do yourself a favor and read this book. No, it’s not a panacea, but it is a bit of existential therapy.

Crisp, eloquent, and inspiring. Carroll gives poetic naturalism a humane discussion, focusing both on the physical and the poetic. The only place I found it lacking was the last section, where courage fails and an overly heavy emphasis on Hume's moral philosophy is put. This last move, in my eyes, is a mistake, as the foundation for poetic naturalism to stand on its own feet is built throughout the rest of the book.

Maybe 3.5? The book covers so much, and sometimes covers it with the same excerpts and examples you’ve already heard (no more trolley problems, please!). Every now and then I felt like I was being led through an argument I’ve had many times before. But the author is smart and earnest and good company, and his application of “poetic naturalism” and “Bayesian probability” is consistent and fair. I’d get a beer with him.

Every day the most intelligent primate on the planet learns more, and learns faster. If you're looking for a cutting edge book on science/physics, and how that knowledge gives insight into our world I would highly recommend this book. Sean Carroll understands the gravity, (no pun intended), of what we know about the universe, and at the same time understands that, in the end, what we don't know keeps us grounded and keeps us searching. Terrific book.

While it loses a little momentum when the discussion turns to morality, and I find Carroll's writing style a little repetitive and slow, this book is a tour de force. Carroll covers an almost impossible number of topics and manages to introduce almost all of them with care. I especially enjoyed his conversations of quantum field theory, entropy and the arrow of time, and reducible complexity. Highly recommended--4.5/5 stars.

I loved this book for its superb exposition of difficult scientific concepts. Reaching the section on Thinking brought great disappointment, however, not because of the neuroscience, which was very simple, but because Mr. Carroll veered off into consciousness, a construct for which there is no scientific evidence, and began parroting the "thought experiments" and poorly constructed arguments of philosophers, which should have no place in a scientific work.

I had higher expectations from this book. Ever since reading "From Eternity To Here: The Quest for the Ultimate Theory of Time", I couldn't wait to get my hands on this one. What I didn't like most is that Carroll steered to much into what can essentially be considered metaphysics, even ethics in some cases. He's a great writer nonetheless, able to present complex ideas of Physics in a way that is both not simplified too much and is also understandable.

Really gave me a clearer understanding of a naturalist argument against God, of the state of our understanding of the physical world, (pretty advanced, though with a long way to go), and how the emergent phenomena of cream swirling in milk parallels the origins of life on earth in an ever increasing entropy world. An ambitious work, but worth reading through to learn about the big picture of the universe we live in.

This book covers the topics of science, religion, consciousness and morale. They are viewed through the lens of the philosophy of poetic naturalism, where there is one natural world and there are many ways of talking about it depending on the aspect. Poetic naturalism resolves some of the puzzles in philosophy and science. The final part of the books discusses the meaning and purpose in our lives if we accept naturalism.

UnderwhelmingI got this book in the hope of having an intriguing, non theistic approach to morality. While the science was above reproach, the approach to answering the question or morality in a universe that's only true all encompassing drive in to increased entropy is lacking. I'm unclear why atheist seem to want to treat non belief as a religion inasmuch as many seem to want to spread the belief as a disciple might.

"Poetic Naturalism is poetic because there are different stories we can tell about the world, many of them capturing some aspects of reality, and all useful in their appropriate context. There's no reason for us to pretend that subjective experiences don't exist, or on the other hand that they are something happening in the brain. They are essential concepts within a way of talking about things happening in our brain, and that makes all the difference."

"The Big Picture" is a grotesque scientific book that holds your attention throughout the book and opens the world of naturalism in its wide of definition. Easy to read, Sean Carroll opened to me a whole new world of so called "cosmos philsophy" in terms of different points of view, theism and atheism. It is adorable to note that his intinsic and definitive analysis to scientific researches, philosophy, physics, humanity and astronomy.

"A person is a diminutive, ephemeral thing, standing smaller in comparison with the universe than a single atom stands to the Earth." -Prologue"Our progress through time is pushed from behind, not pulled from ahead." -Pg. 66"3 billion heartbeats...pure chance can be so kind....in the vastness of space & time that we could be together for 20 years sustains me and is so meaningful."- Ann Druyan Pg. 388"We need some new ground to stand on--or we need to learn how to fly." - Pg 390

Listened to the audio version, narrated by the author. Wow. What a Fantastic book. I was hooked from beginning to end, although I needed to pause it throughout to give time to process what was said along with implications. I appreciate that he took the time to explain everything clearly, while at the same time not watering it down. The book assumes you are willing to work to understand it, and the contents were well worth the effort.

4.5 stars. I don't think I've read any of Carroll's books before, but after reading this I'm definitely going to check him out. His description of credences using Bayesian statistics was very well written and the way he returns to this theme throughout the book was enjoyable. At times the references to other philosophy works got a little too heavy, but all in all, I very much enjoyed the thoughts and ideas Carroll provides here.

430 pages book (470 with annexe and bibliography).Excellent book. Although I disagree with some of the basic ideas and notions of this book, I enjoyed reading it. It encompasses multidisciplinary arguments including physics, chemistry, biology, philosophy, logic and reasoning, computing and artificial intelligence, and ethics and morality.It doesn't matter if you agree with Sean Caroll or not, it suffices to make you think hard and face up the twisted dilemmas out there.

I'll probably need to reread this book if I'm going to remember most of what was in it. Carroll manages to cover a broad range of topics to do with science, covering what seemed like all of modern physics. The mix of science with his own philosophies in a casual writing style made for a nice read. Sometimes his philosophising was a little excessive, and came off as him trying to hard to push his worldview upon us. However still a great informative book.

Intelligently and elegantly written, covering a wide range of scientific subjects and concepts that will interest most audiences. Each topic is approached at a high level and repeats much of the science learnt as a student, so if you are looking at a deep-dive into any of the subjects covered then this may not be the book for you, but if you are looking for an enjoyable and thought provoking take on those subjects then I recommend you read The Big Picture.

If I could pick a book that everyone should read, I think this might be it. The Big Picture is just that--a widely-scoped overview of the universe, philosophy, evolution, consciousness, physics, and more. Sean Carroll does an incredible job making complex topics understandable and seemingly uninteresting topics increasingly interesting. I fail to see how anyone could come away from this book without having a better grasp on the nature of reality.

Without (IMO) being condescending or judgmental Sean does a great job summarizing all the physics and thinking behind his worldview of poetic naturalism. What is a poetic naturalist? It’s an atheist who loves people because really there’s nothing better to do. I really like how deep he gets into what language does to our thinking. How we have different blocks of vocabulary for describing different levels of systems and experience. And we get into trouble when we mix the vocabulary sets.

Wide ranging and clearly expressed overview of everything: from quarks to quantum fields, from cells to consciousness; from deism to naturalism. Carroll's main argument is that there is only the natural world, and our highest functions, including our moral choices, can be explained by the natural world. Although his argument is a little thin in places (such as in the argument about free will and choice), he is ultimately convincing, at least to someone predisposed to his outcome.

Sorry, I love Sean Carroll but I had the hardest time following this book. Maybe it's beyond my intellectual capabilities but I was often bored and skipped through chunks of it. It did have it's interesting parts though, and the questions/points raised are good food for thought. Maybe one day I'll come back to it and give it another go.

I was disappointed. The author thinks he has the whole universe figured out. And that whole meaning of life thing...spoiler alert...according to the author, there is no meaning. You live. You die. It's a process. You have no connection to the universe. The author should have stuck to the physics.

One of the most comprehensive books on the understanding of the world covering Philosophy, Biology, Physics. The author doesn't just explore scientific concepts but also covers how to derive meaning out of them and out of things we don't know yet. It is not at all an easy read and took me almost a month to finish but was worth it.

Very well-written. Covers lots of territory, some of which (like some of the physics) in more detail than I really wanted. He draws it all together at the end very well to show how it all added up to give him his philosophy of life, poetic naturalism. This should provide lots of fodder for discussion by The Sunday Philosophers.

Carroll has an easy manner of discussing difficult topics that is both reasonable and compelling. I especially liked the section on ethics for naturalists. The Big Picture ties in physics and philosophy remarkably well. If you have any interest in rational thought and naturalism this should be a must read.

Physicist Sean Carroll's explanation and justification of poetic naturalism, which explains the universe without the need for God or anything beyond the physical. He does a good job of it, and I'm very glad I read the book. It is a bit of a trudge sometimes, mostly due to his completeness. Don't expect a thriller, but do expect to be enlightened.

This is very informative, entertaining, but also quite deep. It gets into quantum physics a couple of times, sometimes superficially, sometimes in a very extensive way. Anyway, if you're a curious person (or a physicist) it's worth the read. I really liked the "philosophy" of poetic naturalism as presented by the author.

4.5 stars. Sean Carroll is such a pleasure to read. He assumes that the reader is new to particle physics and quantum theory and the like and carefully and easily explains it. This, of course, goes beyond just the physics, as the title implies. Lots of food for thought, here, and definitely worth re-reading.

I enjoyed this book (my actual rating 4.6). Carroll is a theoretical physicist who has a wide range of knowledge. His conversational tone made it a pleasure to read. Two samples of his observations: “100 million neutrinos pass through your body every second,” and “I fell in love with the universe at an early age.”

“There are more things in heaven and Earth, Horatio, Than are dreamt of in your philosophy.”If Horatio had written a book to refute Hamlet, this would be it. The author is very widely read and an excellent synthesist. However, for a reader who already has a basic background in science and philosophy, Shakespeare might be a more interesting place to look for the big picture.

Amazing! The best science book I've ever read. Every adult with any interest but little experience with Science, Math, and Philosophy should read this book! Dr. Carroll has an excellent ability to explain complex subjects to the layman (me) all while presenting an even-handed look at the intersection of Theology, Science, and Morals. Truly an incredible piece of work.

As far as science theorists and or authors go Sean Carroll has become my brand new favorite Physics go to professor and well...if you are missing Hawkings presence in this current configuration of this version of our multi-verse....Carroll will certainly help those of us for whom are still thirsty etc...

The scope of this book ranged from The Big Bang and Core Theory to human consciousness and ethics and how it all fits together. Carroll leads the reader through difficult science to difficult human issues in a thought provoking and soul searching way. The last few pages were so poignant I cried. I love a book that makes me ponder and this one did that in every chapter.

If you want a clearer picture of how the universe works...and I mean nearly every aspect that affects your life...read this book. By the time you are done, you will have a better understanding of this place where you exist and your place in it. If you do and don't, you will have to update your credence somehow.

Sean Carroll claims that he follows the Bayesian reasoning yet all his arguments were very subjective and made no scientific sense at all. His “scientific” reasoning was very general and Sean was avoiding a lot of the details. This was getting annoying and I was not able to read past 3/4 of the book.

I think this is a very wonderful book, a conversation about information, system of information, how it is acquired and perceived, how it effects out view of the world around us, how to make sense of it, and what might be done about it. goes from the outer boudaries of physics, to chemistry to biology and evolution, to sociology and philosophy and to ethics and meaning. fun fun fun

A great introduction to a variety of concepts and fields of study such as physics, quantum theory, evolution, bayes rule, ontology. You may not get much out of parts of the book if you've already studied certain areas in depth, but it serve as a perfect check to fill in any gaps you might have in basic understanding the world we find ourselves in.

It's quite unpleasant (almost without an exception) when scientists in the 21st century try to do philosophy. This is not quite a "fail" as Stephen Hawking's attempts at epistemology, but it is rather pedestrian and obvious if you know anything about history of philosophy. Carroll's books on science or far more interesting because there he actually knows the subject matter.

Truly an excellent tour of physics, biology and statistics. While it wasn't a focus of the book, one thing that really struck me is that Carroll does a better job than most at explaining just exactly why astrology, ESP, 'psychic' phenomena and more are not only bunk but physically incompatible with the laws of the universe we see.

3.5. A physicist takes on philosophy. What results is mostly commonsense, but nothing new or profound. I found myself agreeing with practically everything in the book but didn't feel like I learned anything new. Worth reading if you want a naturalist's perspective on life, but not a must read either.

Sean Carroll speaks and writes well. I like his approach. Moreover, I like to read this kind of books (another example is 'Our Mathematical Universe' by Max Tegmark), that are written by established scientists. They may have the correct authority for introducing philosophical and metaphysical aspects of nature. This book will give you some foods for thought.

I love Sean Carroll's books! Clear thinking, easy to read, matter-of-fact style. This is a big book dealing with a super wide range of topics... Cosmology (Why does the universe exist?), Evolution (How does complexity evolve?), God, Quantum Field Theory, the purpose of life, thinking and freedom. It's a very positive and very enjoyable book.

Illuminating at times, yet many times just drags on. Not as much universe-stuff as I had hoped. Instead, a lot of philosophy, almost all of which I had studied extensively in the past. I especially liked the detailed discussion about the beginning of life, and appreciated the approachable language.

This was a very readable journey into physics, biology, and even which and philosophy. He deals with the hard problem of consciousness, mentions "The Purpose Driven Life", and debunks panpsychism. The time is thoughtful and irenic, different than Dawkins. I was slightly disappointed by the brevity of his chapter on existential therapy. I'll definitely be reading more of his books.

A perfect blend of astronomy and philosophy. Carroll hits on just about everything here from ancient philosophocal dilemas to wacko quantum mechanics theories. I really enjoys the way this book made me think, I highly recommend. I give a 4 star only because I think he gets a little too scientifically in depth on equations and thing like that lol.

Not my favoriteI am a big fan of contemporary science books, especially physics! Though these words may come from a brilliant thinker, my take is this is jumbled and rambling to the point where I tended to disagree with the authors points because I resented the stream of consciousness-like trails he pulled me through. Too brilliant for a little editing?

can’t decide if 4 or 5 stars but this book is STUFFED. this dude goes from hard science to existential crisis mode in 5 seconds flat. wild ride. pRofOUNd. highly recommend to all who are made of star stuff. “The finitude of life lends poignancy to our situations. Each of us will have a last word we say, a last book we read, a last time we fall in love.”

This books is somehow an introduction to almost everything. An introduction to various fields within physics, ideas within philosophy as well as general science. Carroll asks some very hard questions and manages to answer them faithfully. Whether you agree with everything or not it's a great kick-start for a think about all the big questions. Wonderfully written.

Carroll is clear and fairly easy to understand without much heavy physics or math, yet he discusses serious topics such as physics and philosophy that are nowadays usually kept apart. He argues as a self-avowed atheist with the compassion of a religious person, for as he maintains, we do not need religion and a fear of an afterlife to live a moral life.

I listen to Sean Carroll's Mindscape podcast and frequently find myself agreeing with his point of view. So, I just had to listen to his latest book on Audible. I quite like the way he frames his ontology as Poetic Naturalism. I can see myself buying the actual book because there are parts I would like to reread to gain a better understanding.
